revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Counties Manukau District Health Board | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = | founder = | founding_location = | extinction = | merger = | type = | tax_id = | registration_id = | status = | purpose = [[District Health Board (New Zealand)|DHB]] | headquarters = | location = | coords = | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = | sec_gen = | leader_title = Chief Executive | leader_name = Geraint A Martin{{cite web|url=http://www.countiesmanukau.health.nz/assets/About-CMH/Reports-and-planning/Annual-reports-and-plans/2015.11.18-CMDHB-Final-Annual-Report.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 13, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126230621/http://countiesmanukau.health.nz/assets/About-CMH/Reports-and-planning/Annual-reports-and-plans/2015.11.18-CMDHB-Final-Annual-Report.pdf |archivedate=January 26, 2016 }} | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = [[Ministry of Health (New Zealand)|Ministry of Health]] | subsidiaries = Northern Regional Alliance Ltd (33.5%)
healthAlliance NZ Ltd (20%)
NZ Health Innovation Hub Limited (20%) | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = $1.5 billion ([[NZD]]) | budget_year = 2015 | revenue = $1.485 billion ([[NZD]]) | revenue_year = 2015 | disbursements = | expenses = $1.483 billion ([[NZD]]) | expenses_year = 2015 | endowment = | staff = 7,400 | staff_year = 2015 | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|http://www.countiesmanukau.health.nz/}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} The '''Counties Manukau District Health Board''' (CM Health) is a [[district health board]] with the focus on providing healthcare to the Counties Manukau area in southern [[Auckland]], New Zealand. As of 2016, it is responsible for 534,750 residents; or 11% of New Zealand's population.{{cite web|url=http://www.countiesmanukau.health.nz/about-us/our-region/ |title=Our region | Counties Manukau Health |publisher=Countiesmanukau.health.nz |date= |accessdate=2016-06-11}} ==Facilities== [[Middlemore Hospital]] is the largest facility under the management of CM Health, however they manage multiple other facilities, which include Kidz First Children's Hospital, the Manukau Surgery Centre, Pukekohe Hospital, Franklin Memorial Hospital, Botany Downs Maternity Unit and Papakura Maternity Unit as well as dedicated mental health and rehabilitation units. There are also specialised smaller scale health centres referred to as SuperClinics, they are, Manukau SuperClinic and Botany SuperClinic.{{cite web|url=http://www.countiesmanukau.health.nz/our-services/a-z/middlemore-hospital/ |title=Middlemore Hospital | Counties Manukau Health |publisher=Countiesmanukau.health.nz |date= |accessdate=2016-06-11}} ==Localities and diversity== CM Health is divided into four divisions, Otara-Mangere, Manukau, Franklin , and Eastern. These divisions are called Localities. ===Franklin=== Franklin is the largest locality in CM Health and has a population of around 70,000 representing 14% of the CM population. The population of Franklin Locality is a European majority locality with only 27% of the population not being European (17% Maori, 4% Pacific peoples, and 6% Others). {{cite web|url=http://www.countiesmanukau.health.nz/about-us/performance-and-planning/integrated-care/localities/franklin-locality/ |title=Franklin locality | Counties Manukau Health |publisher=Countiesmanukau.health.nz |date= |accessdate=2016-06-11}} ===Otara-Mangere=== Otara-Mangere is the smallest locality under CM Health and accounts for roughly 32% of the CM population at around 166,500. Of the population 110,000 are registered with a doctors practice, 68,000 in [[Mangere]] and 42,000 in [[Otara]]. Included in the Otara-Mangere Locality is the northern portion of [[Papatoetoe]] as well as a small portion of [[Otahuhu]]. The population of the Otara-Mangere Locality is 65% [[Pacific Islander]], 20% [[Māori people|Maori]], 8% [[Ethnic groups in Europe|European]], and 7% other.{{cite web|url=http://www.countiesmanukau.health.nz/about-us/performance-and-planning/integrated-care/localities/otaramangere-locality/ |title=Otara/Mangere locality | Counties Manukau Health |publisher=Countiesmanukau.health.nz |date= |accessdate=2016-06-11}} ===Eastern=== The Eastern Locality geographical area includes urban areas of [[Howick, New Zealand|Howick]], [[Pakuranga]], [[Dannemora, New Zealand|Dannemora]], [[East Tamaki]] and [[Flat Bush]] and extends to the rural areas of [[Beachlands, New Zealand|Beachlands]], [[Maraetai]], [[Clevedon]], Kawakawa Bay and [[Orere Point]]. With a population of 145,000, Eastern Locality holds around 28.5% of the CM Population. Of this 28.5%, 114,000 or 24% of CM Health's population are registered with a general practice within the Eastern Locality. The Easter Locality has the oldest age average of CM Health's jurisdiction with over 16,000 residents over the age of 65. The majority of Eastern Locality is persons of [[Chinese people|Chinese]] and/or [[Indian people|Indian]] descent; it is estimated that over two-thirds of CM Health's Chinese population and one-third of its Indian population live within the Eastern Locality.{{cite web|url=http://www.countiesmanukau.health.nz/about-us/performance-and-planning/integrated-care/localities/eastern-locality/ |title=Eastern locality | Counties Manukau Health |publisher=Countiesmanukau.health.nz |date= |accessdate=2016-06-11}} ===Manukau=== Manukau Locality is the largest by population with 35% representing 187,000 people. Manukau has the largest concentration of people representing 56% of CM Health's total Maori, 37% of its total Pacific population, 53% of its total Indian population, and 24% of Other populations.{{cite web|url=http://www.countiesmanukau.health.nz/about-us/performance-and-planning/integrated-care/localities/manukau-locality/ |title=Manukau locality | Counties Manukau Health |publisher=Countiesmanukau.health.nz |date= |accessdate=2016-06-11}} ==Current board (2016-2019)== Elections for the board are held every three years.{{cite web|url=http://www.aucklandcouncil.govt.nz/EN/ABOUTCOUNCIL/HOWCOUNCILWORKS/ELECTIONS/Pages/Electionresults2016.aspx#cmdhb |title=Election results 2016 |website=Aucklandcouncil.govt.nz |date= |accessdate=2017-01-07}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Member(s) ! Affiliation (if any) |- | Colleen Brown | Team Health |- | Apulu Autagavaia | [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour]] |- | Katrina Bungard | Vision & Voice |- | Catherine Abel-Pattinson | Team Health |- | Lyn Murphy | Independent |- | [[Ashraf Choudhary]] | Labour |- | Dianne Glenn | Team Franklin |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{District health boards}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Medical and health organisations based in New Zealand]] [[Category:New Zealand Crown agents]] [[Category:Auckland Region]] [[Category:Health agencies]]

page.title: Department of Social and Preventive Medicine, University of Malaya

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2013}}
The '''Department of Social and Preventive Medicine''' (popularly known as SPM) is one of 22 teaching departments in the Faculty of Medicine, [[University of Malaya]]. It was formed in 1964, one year after the founding of the Faculty of Medicine in the University of Malaya in Kuala Lumpur. The department are involved in both Undergraduate and Postgraduate teachings.
The [[Master of Public Health]] program was started in 1973 in response to an acute need of the Ministry of Health Malaysia for Medical Offices of Health to serve in the then fast expanding [[rural health services]]. Thus the program during the first decade of its existence was aimed at producing competent public health specialist to serve the rural areas
By 1987, the environment have so changed that at a meeting between the Director General of Health Services of Malaysia and senior staff of the Department of SPM, a new kind of public health officer was required by the Ministry of Health, namely "a multipurpose public health doctor equipped with the managerial skills and able to work in the general public health as well as hospital setting". By 1989, after a review of the curriculum, a new set of objectives were established for MPH programme.
The MPH Graduate should be
# Technically competent in the board field of Public Health; # Equipped with managerial skills; # Able to function as a leader in public services; # Able to work in the Public Health as well as the hospital setting; and # Able to work in the district, state as well as the national levels of the health services.
By 1992, many changes had already taken place in the country as well as in the national health services and it was felt that all these changes had an influence on the practice of public health. It was with this in ming that a concept paper to propose "a system of education or training at the postgraduate level and a career development channel in the field of Public Health in Malaysia" was produced by the Department of Social and Preventive Medicine. This culminated in the initiation of a 4-years training program, the program has further evolve with the addition of the [[Doctor of Public Health]] program.
The graduates originate from the following countries,
# [[China]] # [[Germany]] # [[Indonesia]] # [[India]] # [[Iran]] # [[Libya]] # [[Malaysia]] # [[Mongolia]] # [[Myanmar]] # [[Pakistan]] # [[Papua New Guinea]] # [[Somalia]] # [[Sudan]] # [[United Kingdom]] # [[Yemen]]
They now serve with distinction in the Ministry of Health, universities and various National and International bodies (e.g. [[Malaysian Armed Forces]], WHO ([[World Health Organization]]), [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] (MSF), and in town and city councils) in [[Malaysia]] and around the world.
==See also== * [[Wikiversity:Topic:Community Medicine]]
== External links == * {{Official website|http://spm.um.edu.my|Department of Social and Preventive Medicine official website}}
{{coord missing|Malaysia}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2017}} [[File:Haass.jpg|180px|thumb|left|'''"Saint Doctor", Friedrich Joseph Haass''']] [[File:Тарасенко Тамара Андреевна (портрет работы художника Гормаха Л.Л.).jpg|150px|thumb|'''The first chairman of the boardof the Fund Tamara Tarasenko'''. Painter L.L. Gormakh]]
'''Dr. Haass Social Assistance Fund''' is the first non-profitable [[non-governmental]] charitable organization (NPO) in the [[Soviet Union]], founded on November 26, 1987 in [[Odessa]] ([[USSR]]).<ref name=autogeneratedD>{{Cite web|url = https://cloud.mail.ru/public/efc157d2f49d/%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%BA%D0%BB%D1%8E%D1%87%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5%20%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B8|title = Report of the Standing Committee on Social Policy of the Odessa City Council on May 17, 2000|author = |work = |date = |publisher = }} (Russian)</ref><ref name=autogeneratedB>{{Cite web|url = https://cloud.mail.ru/public/c9d541a80de8/%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BA%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%20%D0%BD%D0%B0%20%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%84%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8|title = Brochure about the Fund (New York, 1991).|author = |work = |date = |publisher = }}</ref><ref name="FDSP">[http://samlib.ru/m/muchnik_a_g/book1954.shtml Books: "Philosophy of dignity, freedom and human rights"] (Russian)</ref><ref name=autogenerated2>[http://www.2000.ua/v-nomere/derzhava/ekspertiza/portret-pravozawitnika-v-socialnom-interereb1-2-b6_1456927399.htm "A Portrait of a Human Rights Activist in the Social Interior" – Newspaper "2000", # 9, March 2, 2016] (Russian)</ref><ref name="drive.google.com">"Hasten to do good things!". – Magazine "Rabotnitsa", № 3, 1989. – https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1uofP2NAJxpZ21ZaC1VWmkzN0k/view?usp=sharing; https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1uofP2NAJxpb2ZfWXQ4YzVyUFk/view?usp=sharing (Russian)</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1uofP2NAJxpRzhkdUNnWXZkQ00/view?usp=sharing «Dr Haass Fund». — Newspaper «Nedelya», № 49,1989.] (Russian)</ref><ref name="People 1990">[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1uofP2NAJxpZFBaUE1NYlJLdE0/view?usp=sharing «People, money, conscience». — Journal «Okhrana truda i sotsialnogo strakhovaniya», № 7, 1990.] (Russian)</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>[http://izvestiya.odessa.ua/ru/2015/11/16/pozabytye-uroki-proshlogo-vmesto-predisloviya «Forgotten lessons of the past instead of a preface». – Newspaper «Odesskiye izvestiya», 14.11.2015.] (Russian)</ref> It is named after a famous Russian philanthropist, "Saint Doctor", [[Friedrich Joseph Haass]] (1780–1853).
The most comprehensive official study of diverse charitable activities of the Fund has found its documentary reflection in the report of the Standing Committee on [[Social Policy]] of the Odessa City Council on May 17, 2000<ref name=autogeneratedD /> as well as in the documentary film about the activity of the Fund<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G7Sf65pIMgY&feature=youtu.be A documentary about the Dr. Haass Fund (1995)] (Russian)</ref> Independent experts of the Standing Committee estimated the Fund charitable assistance to people in need, and to [[social institutions]], at a total amount of more than eight [[million]] US dollars, as of 2000.
== History == Graduates of the [[Faculty of Law]] of [[Odessa State University|Odessa State Mechnikov University]] (OSU) Oleg Kutateladze and [[Alexander Muchnik]]<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref>[http://cyclowiki.org/wiki/%D0%90%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80_%D0%93%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%8C%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%9C%D1%83%D1%87%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA Alexander Muchnik] (Russian)</ref> were the founders of the Fund. OSU Professors supported the creation and formation of the Fund: the Head of the Department of Philosophy [[Tamara Tarasenko]] (1939–1992),<ref>Grebennik G.P. "The portrait of an intellectual in the Odessa interior. Story about Tamara Andreevna Tarasenko and not only about her". – Odessa: Phoenix, 2010. — 176 p. — {{ISBN|978-966-438-215-8}} (Russian)</ref> who became the first chairman of the boardof the Fund, and the [[Dean of the Faculty]] of Law, Doctor of Law, professor, [[Academician]] Anatoly S. Vasilyev (1938–2015),<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cTk6sEGkQbk&feature=youtu.be Interview with A.G.Muchnik about the role of Academician A.S.Vasilyev (1995).] (Russian)</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N_hsp6B-7PI&feature=youtu.be Interview with Academician A.S.Vasilyev about Dr Haass Social Assistance Fund (1995)] (Russian)</ref> who became a member of the Board of the Fund.
== Charity == [[File:Фасад Центра.jpg|thumb|200px|on right|'''The office of Janusz Korczak Institute''']] [[File:Коллектив Центра милосердия имени Матери Марии (г. Одесса, 1990 г.).jpg|thumb|200px|upright|мини|справа|'''The staff of the Mother Maria Mercy Center''']] [[File:Дом с Ангелом 1.jpg|thumb|200px|мини|справа| '''House with the angel''']] [[File:Скан00035.JPG|thumb|200px|мини|справа| '''Autograph of the Hero of Ukraine Boris Litvak ("To Alexander Muchnik with gratitude for participation without which this wonderful center would have never been created. Sicerely yours, Boris Litvak")''']] During its philanthropic mission the Fund has created and funded a number of charitable organizations and programs that provide social, medical and psychological assistance to a large number of lonely [[elderly people]], the disabled, war and labor [[veterans]], sick children, as well as financial support to kindergartens, schools, [[hospitals]] and health centers, various social institutions.<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="drive.google.com"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="People 1990"/>
It is one of the participants of the inaugural [[Convention (meeting)|conference]] of the Soviet Charity and Health Fund (September 16, 1988, Moscow, the USSR).<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" /><ref>"Mercy under the order". – Newspaper "Znamya kommunizma",October 3, 1988 </ref>
To prepare the establishment of a [[free economic zone]] in Odessa on November 23, 1988 the Fund commissioned a group of economists led by Professor Vladimir Dergachyov, to develop the documents entitled "Prospects of Odessa region on the basis of an open economy", which was delivered to the Fund on April 6, 1989 р.<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" /><ref>The article about free economic zones by Dergachyov V. – http://dergachev.ru/Landscapes-of-life/FEZ/index.html</ref>
The Fund founded [[Janusz Korczak Institute of medical rehabilitation of children with central nervous system lesion]] (September 6, 1989, Odessa, the Ukrainian SSR).<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pZJoVw1uAmE&feature=youtu.be (Russian)</ref> For many years [[Doctor of Medicine]], professor, [[UNICEF]] expert Irina Viktorovna Galina has been the leader of the Institute.<ref>[http://vo.od.ua/rubrics/lyudi-dela/29598.php Irina Viktorovna Galina] (Russian)</ref> During its activity the Institute has treated more than 12 thousand children with organic and functional diseases of the central nervous system, such as [[cerebral palsy]], [[mental retardation]], [[Down syndrome]], [[epilepsy]], [[autism]], and so on.<ref>[http://dumskaya.net/news/Mify_o_lyudyah_s_umstvennoj_otstalostyu-003540/"Myths about mentally retarded people have been dispelled in Odessa". — Dumskaya//October 9, 2009] (Russian)</ref><ref>[http://www.odessit.ua/news/odessa/29474-dlya-vospitannikov-reabilitacionnogo-centra-im-yanusha-korchaka-proveli-prazdnichnyy-koncert.html/"A festive concert was held for the pupils of Janusz Korczak Rehabilitation Center". — Odessit.ua//June 4, 2014] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304142637/http://www.odessit.ua/news/odessa/29474-dlya-vospitannikov-reabilitacionnogo-centra-im-yanusha-korchaka-proveli-prazdnichnyy-koncert.html/ |date=March 4, 2016 }} (Russian)</ref><ref>[http://vo.od.ua/rubrics/medicina/28893.php" To understand, to accept, to help with adaptation" – Newspaper "Odessa", # 52 on April 8, 2014] (Russian)</ref><ref>[http://od.vgorode.ua/news/sobytyia/74638/"There will be a new temple in Odessa" – VGORODE.UA on September 15, 2011] (Russian)</ref><ref>[http://od-news.com/2009/02/18/2805/#!/odnewscom/"European-level rehabilitation center works in Odessa" – Vzglyad iz Odessa, February 18, 2009] (Russian)</ref>
[[Mother Maria]] Mercy Center (August 9, 1989, Odessa, the USSR). In its three hospitals, located in Odessa (in Gamarnik street, 13, apt 14; Prospect Mira, 37; and Tereshkova street, 12 "b" apt 21), highly qualified doctors and nurses, under the guardiance of PhD Boris Khersonsky at the beginning and later by Vladimir Gemusov (1939–2014), took care of elderly lonely people. The Center staff also provided medical care and social protection to elderly lonely people at home. Two ambulance cars served the Centre.<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" />
Youth Charitable Institution "Humanist" (May 15, 1990, Odessa, the USSR), which with the active participation of high-school students and students of Odessa secondary and higher educational medical institutions, under the leadership of Lyubov Bogomolova,[20] regularly provided social, medical and psychological care for elderly people who live alone.<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" /> Two ambulance cars served the elderly people.
The Fund responded to individual requests for support from persons and organizations deserving consideration,<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" /> namely:
– Supported solo exhibition of paintings be an Odessa artist Zoya Ivnytskaya in Western Berlin, FRG (October 1989 – January 1990);<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB />
– Provided the necessary support to an Odessa pianist Sergei Terentyev (1990, Odessa,the Ukrainian SSR);<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB />
– Provided financial assistance to the newspaper "Moscow News", whose office was damaged by the fire (March 14, 1990, Moscow, the USSR);<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB />
– Provided financial assistance to the famous Soviet dissident and human rights activist Valery Abramkyn «Humanization of the prison system" (April 23, Moscow, the USSR);<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB />
– Provided financial assistance to the first hospice in the Soviet Union (September 26, 1990, Leningrad, the USSR);<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB />
– Provided financial support to the Institute for Economic Strategies (October 17, 1990, Moscow, the USSR).<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB />
The Fund founded Center for Psychological and Social Support (November 15, 1990, Odessa,the USSR), including youth service helpline, under the supervision of a physician Leopold Mendelson. Every night it provided emergency psychological assistance to young people who found themselves in difficult life situations. Center initiated the creation of the Association of hotlines (1990), the Ukrainian association of telephone consultants (1992), as well as the International Workshop telephone consultants.<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" /><ref name=autogenerated2 />
For training the staff for charitable and social institutions at the Richelieu Lyceum College the Fund created Philanthropic college named after Alexander Men on the base of Richelieu Lyceum (January 1, 1990, Odessa, the Ukrainian SSR). The head of it was a teacher of Mathematics from the Lyceum Dora Chorokayeva.<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" />
Along with the building concern "Primorskiy" (Yuriy Kulbachenko) the Fund organized the program of free renovation of apartments of poor lonely elderly people. The programme was carried out under the guidance of an experienced builder Vladimir Anenberg (1921–2004).<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" /><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gj7HEyGVPa4&feature=youtu.be Interview of Muchnik A. about free renovation of flats (1995)]{{ref-ru}}</ref>
It created the first in the country financial company – Joint-stock financial investment company "Fund" (May 7, 1991, Odessa, the Ukrainian SSR) – which was designed to operate on the principles of philanthropic business. Charitable and social organizations became its stockholders.<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" /><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z3P5OWpphBg&feature=youtu.be Interview with president of JSFIC "Fund" V.  Marevskiy (1995 р.)]{{ref-ru}}</ref><ref>[http://vybor.ua/article/grazhdanskoe_obschestvo/po-kom-zvonit-kolokol-12-09-2009-g.html «For whom the bell tolls?». — Newspaper «Golos Ukrainy», № 171,12.09.2009 ] {{ref-ru}}</ref>
On January 26, 1991 together with the newspaper "Vechernyaya Odessa" the Fund appealed to all citizens of Odessa, non-governmental organizations, labor groups, government bodies, people's deputies and their councils to create a necessary social citywide programme "Miloserdiye" (Mercy) to ensure social assistance for each person in need<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" /><ref>"Dear fellow citizens!". – Newspaper "Vechernyaya Odessa", January 26, 1991</ref>
The Fund initiated the establishment of the Association of Charitable organizations in Odessa (October 16, 1991). Its government was to be formed of journalists, in order to promote the process of establishment, operation and protection of charitable organizations, willing to work in Odessa.<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" /><ref>"Save our souls". – Newspaper "Оdesskiy politekhnik", October 18, 1991 </ref>
The Fund represented by the Head Alexander Muchnik contributed to the creation of the Center for Rehabilitation of Disabled Children "Maibutnye" (Future), better known as the "House with the angel".<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref>[https://cloud.mail.ru/public/tGE9hA1V4aaS/%D0%9F%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BC%D0%BE%20%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83%20%D0%B8%D0%B7%20%D0%9E%D0%9E%D0%9D A letter of the Head of the UN Department in Vienna to president of Dr Haass Social Assistance Fund Boris Litvak (3.06.1993 р.)]{{ref-en}}</ref>
The Fund financed the treatment of a cancer patient at the Medical Center "Cyber Clinic of Spizhenko." (September 17, 2014; September 24, 2015; October 9, 2015).<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==International relationships== [[File:Perspekteves1.jpg|180px|thumb|on right|'''Brochure about Dr. Haass Social Assistance Fund (1991, New York City)''']] The Fund organized the first in the country international conference of charitable organizations "Kindness and peace" ( October 4–7, 1990, Odessa, the Ukrainian SSR).<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogeneratedB /><ref name="FDSP" />
Fruitful activity of the Fund fairly quickly gained international recognition.<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name=autogenerated2 />
On May 28, 1991 A. G. Muchnik made a presentation on the history and activities of the Fund in the Center for the Study of Philanthropy (New York City, United States), and a brochure was published by the Centre and distributed among the US charitable organizations.<ref name="FDSP" />
On July 15, 1991 Muchnik gave a presentation on the activities of the Fund in the United Nations Office at Vienna Centre for Social Development and Humanitarian Affairs ([[Vienna]], [[Austria]]).<ref>[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1uofP2NAJxpaWJKeHpnT2pUY3c/view?usp=sharing&pli=1 Group photo of the participants of the seminar in the UN Center with A. G. Muchnik (Vienna, 1991 )]</ref>
On November 24–29, 1992 Dr Haaz Social Assistance Fund sent Hero of Ukraine Boris Litvak as the president of the Fund to a seminar of the UN Department in Vienna.<ref>[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1uofP2NAJxpYnc1VENfc0lMZGc/view?usp=sharing Boris Litvak is in a group photo of the participants of the UN Department seminar in Vienna (Ausria, 1992 р.)]</ref> On June 3, 1993 Head of the Department of the UN in Vienna Henry Sokalski sent a letter to the president of Dr Haaz Social Assistance Fund, with a statement of full support from his part, and calling for future sponsors to assist the project of Children's rehabilitation center in Odessa.<ref name=autogeneratedD /><ref name="FDSP" />
The Partner is the Society of friends of Dr. F.J. Haass<ref>[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1uofP2NAJxpNjlkVWNwMkYtY0k/view?pref=2&pli=1 German newspaper, 10.08.1994.] (Russian)</ref> ([[Bad Münstereifel]], Germany).
== The Fund in mass-media == * "Co-operatives to mercy service".- Newspaper "Izvestiya", February 9, 1988 * "Hasten to do good things!". – Journal "Rabotnitsa", № 3,1989 * "Dr Haass Social Assistance Fund". – Newspaper "Nedelya", № 49, 1989 * "To die according to the instruction". – Newspaper "Trud", January 24, 1990 * "Instruction instead of soul ". – Newspaper "Trud", March 3, 1990 * "Dr Haass Fund". – Newspaper "Novorossiyskiy telegraph" № 1, 1990 * "People, money, conscience". – Journal "Okhrana truda i socialnogo strakhovaniya" № 7, 1990 * "The pass-word of mercy is Dr Haass". – Newspaper "Vechernyaya Odessa", June 3, 1991 * "Save our souls". – Newspaper "Odesskiy polytekhnik", October 18, 1991 * "Harbourage of hope". – Newspaper "Vechernyaya Odessa", November 20, 1991 * "Humanists". – Newspaper "Vechernyaya Odessa", April 7, 1992 * "Letters from Dr Haass Fund". – Newspaper "Vechernyaya Odessa", December 5, 1995 * "Who cares for you, old people?". – Newspaper "Odesskiye izvestiya", March 22, 1996 * "For whom the bell tolls?". – Newspaper "Odesskiy vestnik", December 3, 1998 * "The island of welfare". – Newspaper "Odesskiy vestnik", December 24, 1998 * "How we learned to donate beggars". – Newspaper "Yug", November 23, 2002 * "Hasten to do good things…". – Newspaper "Vechernyaya Odessa", November 26, 2002 * "Rebound". – Newspaper "Odesskiye izvestiya", December 4, 2002 * "Forgotten lessons of the past instead of a preface  – Newspaper "Odesski visti", November 14, 2015 * "A Portrait of a Human Rights Activist in the Social Interior" – Newspaper "2000", № 9, March 2, 2016

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2600:1:B230:3A4F:14CF:97C5:6E79:EB22|2600:1:B230:3A4F:14CF:97C5:6E79:EB22]] ([[User talk:2600:1:B230:3A4F:14CF:97C5:6E79:EB22|talk]]): Unsourced, drunk grammar. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{other uses}} [[File:Arrest.jpg|thumb|right|A sobering-up cell in Norway. It is easy to clean with minimal features.]] A '''drunk tank''' is a [[prison cell|jail cell]] or separate facility accommodating people who are [[drunkenness|intoxicated]], especially with [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]].<ref name=independent>{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/drunk-tanks-and-minimum-prices-to-help-britain-sober-up-6917683.html | title='Drunk tanks' and minimum prices to help Britain sober up | last1=Morris | first1= Nigel | date= 15 February 2012 | publisher=The Independent | accessdate=16 February 2012}}</ref> Some such facilities are mobile, and may be spoken of as "booze buses".
Traditionally, and in some jurisdictions currently, the circumstances of drunk-tank occupants may vary widely, as to whether in fact intoxicated, whether willingly there, whether isolated to protect them from others, confined to protect others from them, or simply permitted to find shelter, and whether legally under arrest, charged with an offense, or neither. Those in need of more long-term treatment may be referred to a [[drug rehabilitation|rehabilitation center]].
==Europe== In some countries of Europe, such modern institutions are known by names that may be translated as "[[sobriety|sobering]]-up station" or similar.
===Czech Republic=== In the [[Czech Republic]] the name is ''Protialkoholní záchytná stanice'', colloquially ''Záchytka''. The first such institution in [[Czechoslovakia]] was opened in 1951 by psychiatrist [[Jaroslav Skála]];<ref name="British lists">[http://www.blisty.cz/art/28607.html British lists]</ref> its first patient was a Russian naval engineer.<ref name="British lists"/> During its first 30 years of service, [[Prague]]'s sobering-up station treated over 180,000 people. Other facilities in the country treated over 1,000,000 people. During its peak in Czechoslovakia, there were over 63 such institutions.<ref>[http://www.czsk.net/svet/clanky/osobnosti/skalajaroslav.html Czechoslovak world]</ref>
===Estonia=== In [[Estonia]], {{lang|et|kainestusmaja}} (sobering up house) exist in the biggest cities. Most of the clients there are brought forcefully by police to sober up if a person poses a threat to the public or themselves. One will not be released until sober (up to 24 hours).
===Poland=== In [[Poland]] a sobering-up chamber (''Izba wytrzeźwień'') exists in bigger cities. As of 2013, there were 52 in Poland, and each year they host about 300,000 people.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dziennikzachodni.pl/artykul/746121,izba-wytrzezwien-niczym-hotel-trzygwiazdkowy-niezupelnie-zobacz-zdjecia,id,t.html|title=Izba wytrzeźwień niczym hotel trzygwiazdkowy? Niezupełnie [ZOBACZ ZDJĘCIA]|last=Cichy|first=Sławomir|work=Dziennikzachodni.pl|access-date=2017-07-02|language=pl}}</ref> Being drunk by itself is not an offence, but police may place a person in a drunk tank if they're found wandering on roads, during harsh weather etc. through they will often be returned to their houses; many people taken to the drunk tanks are declared violent and a danger for others.<ref name=":0" />
Sobering-up chambers can charge fees just like hotels, and they often chose the most expensive price allowed by law, which is why they are often called "the most expensive hotel in town".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://krakow.onet.pl/najdrozszy-hotel-w-krakowie-jeszcze-drozszy/10zb7|title=Najdroższy "hotel" w Krakowie - jeszcze droższy|date=2014-05-08|work=Onet Kraków|access-date=2017-07-02|language=pl-PL}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lublin.wyborcza.pl/lublin/1,48724,20456244,izba-wytrzezwien-dziala-a-pijani-nadal-trafiaja-do-szpitali.html|title=Izba wytrzeźwień działa, a pijani nadal trafiają do szpitali. Dlaczego?|last=|first=|date=26 July 2016|website=lublin.wyborcza.pl|access-date=2017-07-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rmf24.pl/fakty/news-izba-wytrzezwien-najdrozsza-noclegownia-w-szczecinie,nId,228143|title=Izba wytrzeźwień - najdroższa noclegownia w Szczecinie|last=FM.|first=RMF|access-date=2017-07-02}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
===Russia=== {{Further|Alcohol consumption in Russia}} [[File:Вытрезвитель при Московской части Петербурга.jpg|thumb|One of the early ones, [[St. Petersburg]], 1914. The newly delivered clients are piled up on the floor, while sobering men are sitting or standing up against the walls]] Such institutions, known as ''Vytrezvitel'' ({{lang-ru|Вытрезвитель}}, literally a "''soberator''"), were introduced in 1904 in [[Tula, Russia|Tula]], Russia, by Fedor Archangelskiy, a surgeon.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tounb.tula.net/Tula/Person_zdrav/arhangelskiy.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060825235359/http://tounb.tula.net/Tula/Person_zdrav/arhangelskiy.htm |archivedate=2006-08-25 |df= }}</ref> The reason that Tula pioneered the issue, not [[St. Petersburg]] or [[Moscow]], was because [[Tula Arms Plant]] weaponmakers were [[freezing to death]] in snowbanks on the backstreets of the city on a daily basis right after the salary was paid. The plant's management could not afford to lose their best and most skilled craftsmen, it took them a lot of time to substitute the departed, so they supported the effort. Back then the [[Tsar]]'s government didn't pay much attention to the Vytrezvitels, they were locally managed by municipal authorities and volunteers on their own discretion, because the unskilled workforce was so cheap that nobody really cared much about frozen and drowned drunks. It was the [[bolsheviks]], who didn't neglect their labour force and did pay much attention to institutionalize the sobering procedures and all the people involved, in order to prevent drunk workers from freezing or drowning somewhere unsupervised, or causing other troubles. In 1940 the Vytrezvitels became state-run facilities, they were detached as separate units within the [[NKVD]] and later [[MVD]] structure, [[police patrol]]s and [[Voluntary People's Druzhina|DNDs]], dispatched for their routine raids, collected drunks from the streets to [[police van]]s, moving them to Vytrezvitels and holding them in custody until they sober up, employing force if necessary. Rampant and disorderly drunks or otherwise inappropriately behaving persons, as well as [[DTs]] and [[Alcohol-related dementia|alcohol-]] or narcotics-triggered mental cases were handed over to medical authorities, who had then and have now [[Psychiatric technician|specially detailed medical personnel]], whose primary mission is to neutralize, or subdue into submission, and drag disorderly drunks into a ward, and forcibly administer medications if required.
The [[Awards of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia|Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia issued a medal]] to commemorate the 70th anniversary of state-run Vytrezvitels.
===Sweden=== In [[Sweden]] the sobering-up units are located at police stations around the country. Colloquially known as "fyllecell" or drunk cell, the cell is for holding people who are too intoxicated to take care of themselves or when their intoxication poses a danger to themselves or other people. Being drunk in public is not an offense in Sweden and does not lead to any charges, but repeat "offenders" can have their driver's license revoked.{{Citation needed|reason=whole section on Sweden is without sources.|date=June 2017}}
===Switzerland=== In Switzerland, intoxicated persons can be placed into a sobering-up cell when they pose a danger to themselves or society. While public intoxication is not a crime ''per se'', some police departments assess a fee for the use of their facilities and the related personnel costs incurred by the intoxicated party. For instance, the [[Zürich]] [[municipal police|Stadtpolizei]] charges 450-600 [[Swiss franc]]s for a night in the ''ZAB'', or "Zürich Sobering-up and Supervision Site" ({{lang-de|Zürcher Ausnüchterungs- und Betreuungsstelle}}), which is informally referred to as "Hotel Suff" ("Hotel Booze").<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.tagesanzeiger.ch/zuerich/stadt/im-hotel-suff-landen-viele-auswaertige/story/10279665 |title=Im «Hotel Suff» übernachten viele Auswärtige |date=29 January 2017 |accessdate=July 20, 2018 |work=[[Tages-Anzeiger]] }}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{See also|Intoxication in English law}} In the [[United Kingdom]], the idea of privately run drunk tanks (or "welfare centres"), separate from police stations and funded by the penalties issued against those held there, was discussed in 2013 and gained support from the [[Association of Chief Police Officers]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-24135219 "Acpo issues 'drunk tanks' call to tackle disorder"]. BBC News, 18 September 2013.</ref> Mobile drunk tanks, also known as "booze buses", and officially as "alcohol recovery centres", have since been introduced in some cities ([[Bristol]] being the first to do so).<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/health-42506706 "Drunk tanks may become norm, NHS boss warns 'selfish' revellers"]. BBC News, 29 December 2017.</ref> Newcastle calls its bus a "safe haven van" and parks it next to [[St John Ambulance]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Emergency services join forces to keep Christmas partygoers safe|url=http://www.itv.com/news/tyne-tees/2017-12-16/emergency-services-join-forces-to-keep-christmas-partygoers-safe/|accessdate=30 December 2017|work=ITV News|language=en}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Public intoxication]] * [[Sobriety checkpoint]] * [[Short-term effects of alcohol consumption]]

==External links== * [http://ekonomika.idnes.cz/prvni-zachytnou-stanici-na-svete-vymysleli-v-praze-fhn-/destilaty.asp?c=A060518_100430_destilaty_pal History of sobering-up stations] {{cs icon}}
[[Category:Imprisonment and detention]] [[Category:Drug and alcohol rehabilitation centers]] [[Category:Alcohol in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Alcohol in Estonia]] [[Category:Alcohol in Poland]] [[Category:Alcohol abuse in Russia]] [[Category:Alcohol abuse in the United Kingdom]]

'''Emotional exhaustion''' is a chronic state of physical and [[emotional]] depletion that results from excessive job and/or personal demands and continuous [[Stress (biology)|stress]].<ref name=Wright98>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0021-9010.83.3.486 |vauthors=Wright TA, Cropanzano R |title=Emotional exhaustion as a predictor of job performance and voluntary turnover |journal=J Appl Psychol |volume=83 |issue=3 |pages=486–93 |date=June 1998 |pmid=9648526 |url=http://content.apa.org/journals/apl/83/3/486}}</ref> It describes a feeling of being emotionally overextended and exhausted by one's work. It is manifested by both physical [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]] and a sense of feeling psychologically and emotionally "drained".<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1099-1379(199703)18:2<101::AID-JOB788>3.0.CO;2-Y |author=Zohar D. |title=Predicting burnout with a hassle-based measure of role demands |journal=Journal of Organizational Behavior |volume=18 |issue=2 |pages=101–115 |year=1997 |jstor=3100244}}</ref>
==Burnout== Most emotional exhaustion research has been guided by Maslach's and Jackson's three-component conceptualization of [[Burnout (psychology)|burnout]]. This model suggests burnout consists of three interrelated parts: emotional exhaustion, [[depersonalization]], and diminished personal accomplishment. Diminished personal accomplishment refers to negative evaluations of the [[Self (psychology)|self]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Maslach C. |title=The Burnout: The Cost of Caring |publisher=Prentice Hall |location=Engelwood Cliffs |year=1982 |isbn=0-13-091231-X }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author1=Maslach C. |author2=Jackson S.E. |title=The Maslach Burnout Inventory |publisher=Consulting Psychologists Press |location=Palo Alto, CA |year=1986 |edition=2nd |isbn=99963-45-77-7 }}</ref><ref name=Maslach97>{{cite book |author1=Maslach C. |author2=Leiter M.P. |title=The truth about burnout: How organizations cause personal stress and what to do about it |publisher=Jossey-Bass |location=San Francisco, CA |year=1997 |url=http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0787908746.html |isbn=0-7879-0874-6 }}</ref>
==Determinants==
The level of emotional exhaustion which is experienced by an employee is influenced by a variety of determinants, such as: personal resources, [[coping strategies]], [[emotions and culture|emotional culture]], and supervisory regulation of [[emotional labor#display rules|display rules]].
===Personal resources=== Personal resources, such as status, social support, money or shelter, may reduce or prevent an employee's emotional exhaustion.
According to the [[Conservation of Resources theory]] (COR), people strive to obtain, retain and protect their personal [[Resource (economics)|resources]], either instrumental (e.g., money or shelter), [[social]] (e.g., social support or status) or [[psychological]] (e.g., self-esteem or sense of autonomy). The COR's theory suggest that people must invest resources in order to protect against resource loss, recover from losses, and regain resources. Therefore, those with greater resources are less vulnerable to resource loss and more capable of orchestrating resource gain, whereas, for those with fewer resources, ongoing resource loss may result in a rapid influential loss spiral.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0003-066X.44.3.513 |author=Hobfoll SE |title=Conservation of resources. A new attempt at conceptualizing stress |journal=Am Psychol |volume=44 |issue=3 |pages=513–24 |date=March 1989 |pmid=2648906 |url=http://content.apa.org/journals/amp/44/3/513}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/1089-2680.6.4.307 |author=Hobfoll S.E. |title=Social and psychological resources and adaptation |journal=Review of General Psychology |volume=6 |pages=307–324 |year=2002 |issue=4 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/1464-0597.00062 |author=Hobfoll S.E. |title=The influence of culture, community and the nested-self in the stress process: Advancing conservation of resources theory |journal=Applied Psychology: An International Review |volume=50 |pages=337–421 |year=2001 |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/bpl/apps/2001/00000050/00000003/art00001 |issue=3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=Hobfoll S.E. |title=Stress, Culture, and Community |publisher=Plenum Press |location=New York |year=1998 |isbn=0-306-45942-6 }}</ref>
In a [[field study]], those experiencing higher levels of job [[autonomy]] (the freedom to take initiative and exercise discretion in decision-making), low task complexity, supervisory support, and the [[internal locus of control]] (a tendency to attribute events to one's own control; such as the tendency to attribute a success to internal causes, like one's ability or effort, rather than external causes, such as good luck), tend to experience lower degrees of emotional exhaustion.<ref name="ito">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0001-8791(02)00033-7 |author1=Ito J. |author2=Brotheridge C. |title=Resources, coping strategies, and emotional exhaustion: A conservation of resources perspective |journal=Journal of Vocational Behavior |volume=63 |pages=490–509 |year=2003 |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/els/00018791/2003/00000063/00000003/art00033 |issue=3}}</ref>
Similarly, researchers reveal that even though higher degree of using [[emotional labor#Emotion regulation|emotion regulation]] on the job is related to higher levels of employees' emotional exhaustion, when employees believe that they have autonomy in their job behaviors, emotion regulation, that is otherwise exhausting, is not associated with exhaustion at all.<ref name="grandey_2005">{{cite journal |vauthors=Grandey AA, Fisk GM, Steiner DD |title=Must "service with a smile" be stressful? The moderating role of personal control for American and French employees |journal=J Appl Psychol |volume=90 |issue=5 |pages=893–904 |date=September 2005 |pmid=16162062 |doi=10.1037/0021-9010.90.5.893 |url=http://content.apa.org/journals/apl/90/5/893}}</ref>
Another field study, basing on a [[sample (statistics)|sample]] of call-center workers in a large telecommunications corporation, indicate that employees who are highly identified with the service work, possess higher levels of [[self-efficacy]] (the belief in one's ability to succeed;<ref>see [[Albert Bandura]]</ref>), and receive social support from their supervisors, are less likely to experience emotional exhaustion.<ref name="wilk">{{cite journal |vauthors=Wilk SL, Moynihan LM |title=Display rule "regulators": the relationship between supervisors and worker emotional exhaustion |journal=J Appl Psychol |volume=90 |issue=5 |pages=917–27 |date=September 2005 |pmid=16162064 |doi=10.1037/0021-9010.90.5.917 |url=http://content.apa.org/journals/apl/90/5/917}}</ref>
===Coping strategies=== {{Main|Coping strategies}} Researchers suggest that emotional exhaustion may be a result of using inadequate [[strategies]] in order to cope with problematic events on the job.
Accordingly, there are empirical evidences that employees who tend to use more [[control strategies]], which are considered more productive strategies (concerned with addressing the situation; such as direct action and help seeking) tend to experience lower levels of emotional exhaustion than do those who tend to use more [[escape strategies]], which are considered inadequate strategies (used to avoid problems; such as [[avoidance coping|avoidance]] and [[resignation]] with the problematic situation).<ref name="ito"/>
===Emotional culture===
Regional and national [[cultures]] have been shown to have different norms for [[emotional expression]]s,<ref>{{cite book |author=Ekman P. |chapter=Universals and cultural differences in facial expressions of emotions |editor=Cole J. |title=Nebraska symposium on motivation 1971 |publisher=University of Nebraska Press |location=Lincoln |year=1972 |pages=207–283 }}</ref> and vary in their expectations for regulating and expressing emotions in the workplace.<ref>Cooper, D., Doucet, L., & Pratt, M. (2003, August). I'm not smiling because I like you: Cultural differences in emotional displays at work. Paper presented at the Academy of Management, Seattle, Washington.</ref> Such differences are part of the emotional culture of those cultures. For example, some cultures are more institutionally-oriented, with strong norms about regulating emotions to fulfill institutional roles and standards, whereas other cultures are more impulsively-oriented that value expressing unregulated emotions.<ref name="gordon">{{cite book |author=Gordon S.L. |chapter=Institutional and impulsive orientations in selective appropriating emotions to self |editor1=Franks D.D. |editor2=McCarthy D. |title=The sociology of emotions: Original essays and research papers |publisher=JAI Press |location=Greenwich, CT |year=1989 |pages=115–136 }} </ref>
An example of a culture with a strong institutional-orientation toward emotions is the [[United States]], due to the strong American norm to act positively and hide negative [[feeling]]s ("the service with a smile" norm);<ref>{{cite book |author=Schneider D.J. |chapter=Tactical self-presentations: Toward a broader conception |editor=Tedeschi J.T. |title=Impression management theory and social psychological research |publisher=Academic Press |location=New York |year=1981 |pages=23–40 }} </ref> whereas [[France]] can be used as an example of a country with a more [[impulsivity|impulsive]]-orientation toward emotions.<ref> {{cite journal |author1=Hallowell R. |author2=Bowen D.E. |author3=Knoop C.I. |title=Four seasons goes to Paris |journal=Academy of Management Executive |volume=16 |issue=4 |pages=7–24 |year=2002 |doi=10.5465/AME.2002.8951308 }}</ref>
People within cultures that tend to use an impulsive orientation to understand and evaluate social situations are likely to feel more personal control over their expressions than people within institutional-oriented cultures, resulting in more of a buffer against strain and emotional exhaustion.<ref name="gordon" />
On the basis of those arguments, an organizational [[research]] investigated the influence of emotional culture on the degree of emotional exhaustion experienced by employees who work on jobs that include interaction with clients and [[emotional labor]] demands. In this study, among employees working at such jobs, those who belonged to more impulsive-oriented culture (France) showed lower degrees of emotional exhaustion, than those who belonged to more institutional-oriented culture (U.S.).<ref name="grandey_2005" />
===Supervisory regulation of "display rules"=== Supervisors are likely to be important definers of interpersonal demands at the job level, given their direct influence on worker's beliefs about high-performance expectations. Moreover, supervisors' impressions of the importance of display rules (the rules about what kind of [[emotions]] are allowed to be expressed on the job) influence the employees' impressions of these display rules.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S1053-4822(02)00048-7 |author=Zapf D. |title=Emotion work and psychological well-being. A review of the literature and some conceptual considerations |journal=Human Resource Management Review |volume=12 |pages=237–268 |year=2002 |url=http://web.uni-frankfurt.de/fb05/psychologie/Abteil/ABO/forschung/emoarbeit_lit2_e.htm |issue=2 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070623000624/http://web.uni-frankfurt.de/fb05/psychologie/Abteil/ABO/forschung/emoarbeit_lit2_e.htm |archivedate=2007-06-23 |df= }} </ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0021-9010.88.2.284 |vauthors=Diefendorff JM, Richard EM |title=Antecedents and consequences of emotional display rule perceptions |journal=J Appl Psychol |volume=88 |issue=2 |pages=284–94 |date=April 2003 |pmid=12731712 |url=http://content.apa.org/journals/apl/88/2/284}}</ref>
Recent study also suggests that employees who hold the same job (e.g., call center representatives) may experience the same "display rules" differently if they work for different supervisors, who vary in the emphasis they place on their subordinates' interpersonal role requirements, and by so, experience different levels of emotional exhaustion. Such that having a supervisor who places greater importance on interpersonal job demands results in greater emotional exhaustion (especially for those subordinates who have low [[career]] [[Identity (social science)|identity]]) .<ref name="wilk" />
===Social interaction model of effects on work strain=== Current models of how emotion regulation impacts strain focus on ''intraindividual'' processes that operate within the mind and body of the person regulating the emotion, but these models have several limitations.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Cote S. |title=A social interaction model of the effects of emotion regulation on work strain |journal=Academy of Management Review |volume=30 |issue=3 |pages=509–530 |year=2005 |doi=10.5465/AMR.2005.17293692 }}</ref> # Research indicates that emotion regulation is sometimes positively, sometimes negatively and sometimes not associated with strain.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Barsade S.G. |author2=Brief A.P. |author3=Spataro S.E. |chapter=The affective revolution in organizational behavior: The emergence of a paradigm |editor=Greenberg J. |title=Organizational Behavior: The state of the science |publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum Associates |location=Hillsdale, NJ |year=2003 |pages=3–52 |edition=2nd }}</ref> The intraindividual models do not predict when strain increases or decreases. # The existing models do not distinguish between amplification and suppression of emotion, even though results tend to differ for them. # These models do not refer to the social or ''interpersonal'' functions of emotions.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Frijda N.H. |author2=Mesquita B. |chapter=The social roles and functions of emotions |editor1=Kitayama S. |editor2=Markus H.R. |title=Emotion and culture: Empirical studies of mutual influence |publisher=American Psychological Association |location=Washington, DC |year=1994 |pages=51–87 }}</ref> # They also do not explain the different effects that different discrete emotions have on strain (e.g. pleasant vs. unpleasant).
Cote (2005) suggests a social interaction model that takes into account these limitations. In this model, work strain is predicted according to: # The type and authenticity of the emotion expressed by a sender in an interpersonal situation. # Receiver's skill of decoding emotion display. # Sender's response to receiver's reaction.
According to Cote (2005), interpersonal feedback is far more potent than intraindividual feedback, and dominates if the two processes are in opposition. The social interaction model suggests an alternate route by which to proceed with theory building and future research.
==Implications== Researches have linked emotional exhaustion to a plethora of ailments, and a general breakdown in feelings of community.<ref name=Maslach97/> However, a growing body of research has begun to demonstrate that emotional exhaustion can have deleterious consequences for organizations as well;
For example, Russell Cropanzano and his colleagues, in their two field studies, indicate that exhausted employees show lower [[organizational commitment]], lower [[job performance]], less [[organizational citizenship behavior]]s (OCB) directed toward the organization (OCBO) and their supervisors (OCBS), and higher [[Turnover (employment)|turnover]] intentions. They suggest that emotional exhaustion can be seen as a cost that qualifies the value of any benefits received through employment, and so that an organization, which overworks its employees to the point of emotional exhaustion, may be seen as unfair.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0021-9010.88.1.160 |author1=Cropanzano R. |author2=Rupp D.E. |author3=Byrne Z.S. |title=The relationship of emotional exhaustion to work attitudes, job performance and organizational citizenship behaviors |journal=Journal of Applied Psychology |volume=88 |issue=1 |pages=160–9 |year=2003 |url=http://www.ilir.uiuc.edu/rupp-papers/CropanzanoRuppByrneJAP2003.pdf |pmid=12675403 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100215224016/http://www.ilir.uiuc.edu/rupp-papers/CropanzanoRuppByrneJAP2003.pdf |archivedate=2010-02-15 |df= }}</ref>
Similarly, [[longitudinal study|longitudinal studies]] found that exhausted employees show not only lower job performance, but also more absences, and greater likelihood of seeking [[employment]] elsewhere (actual voluntary turnover).<ref name=Wright98/><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/job.252 |author1=Grandey A. |author2=Dickter D. |author3=Sin H.P. |title=The customer is not always right: Customer aggression and emotion regulation of service employees |journal=Journal of Organizational Behavior |volume=25 |issue=3 |pages=397–418 |year=2004 |url=http://www.personal.psu.edu/aag6/JOB252.pdf |format=PDF}} </ref>
==See also== *[[Organizational justice]] *[[Perceived organizational support]] *[[Perceived psychological contract violation]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== {{refbegin}}
*{{cite journal |author1=Hendrix W.H. |author2=Robbins T. |author3=Miller J. |author4=Summers T.P. |title=Effects of procedural and distributive justice on factors predictive of turnover |journal=Journal of Social Behavior & Personality |volume=13 |issue=4 |pages=611–632 |year=1998 }} *{{cite journal |author=Kahill S. |title=Symptoms of professional burnout: A review of the empirical evidence |journal=Canadian Psychology |volume=29 |issue=3 |pages=284–297 |year=1988 |doi=10.1037/h0079772 }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/257021 |author1=Wayne S.J. |author2=Shore L.M. |author3=Liden R.C. |title=Perceived organizational support and leader-member exchange: A social exchange perspective |jstor=257021 |journal=Academy of Management Journal |volume=40 |issue=1 |pages=82–111 |year=1997 }} {{refend}}
==External links== * http://web.uni-frankfurt.de/fb05/psychologie/Abteil/ABO/forschung/emoarbeit_e.htm

{{Infobox organization | name = Engineering World Health | logo = EWH logo.png | logo_size = 125px | founded_date = 2001, [[Memphis, Tennessee]] | area_served = Global | focus = [[Clinical engineering]] | homepage = [http://ewh.org/ ewh.org] }}
'''Engineering World Health''' ('''EWH''') is a [[non-profit organization]] that works with [[hospitals]] and [[clinics]] that serve resource-poor communities of the [[developing world]]. EWH's focus is on the repair and maintenance of [[medical equipment]] - rather than donation - and on building local capacity to manage and maintain the equipment without international aid.
Engineering professors [[Robert Malkin]] and Mohammad Kiani established EWH in Memphis in 2001. In 2004, Dr. Malkin and EWH relocated to [[Duke University]], which has been an active partner since that time. As a result of this partnership, EWH is headquartered in [[Durham, North Carolina|Durham, NC]]. In 2008, EWH received a multi-year grant from the Wallace H. Coulter Foundation.
==Summer & January Institutes== Engineering World Health's signature program is the Summer & January Institutes. These service abroad programs engage university-level science and engineering students to use their skills and knowledge to make a direct impact on hospitals in developing countries. Participants spend three to nine weeks in [[Nicaragua]], [[Rwanda]], [[Tanzania]], [[Guatemala]], [[Cambodia]], or [[Nepal]] learning hands-on technical skills and the local language, and then working in local hospitals to install, repair, and maintain medical equipment. Participants also train local staff, empowering them to use and maintain equipment, to create lasting improvements in partner hospitals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ewh.org/students/summer-institute/program|title=Overview|website=www.ewh.org|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref>
Since 2004, over 600 participants have repaired almost 5,800 pieces of hospital equipment, worth an estimated US$12 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ewh.org/news/annual-reports|title=Annual Reports|website=www.ewh.org|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref>
==BMET Training Program==
Seeking a sustainable solution to hospital equipment repair, Engineering World Health started a [[biomedical equipment technician]] (BMET) training program in late 2009, in partnership with the [http://www.gefoundation.com/ GE Foundation]. Through a three to four year curriculum tailored to each country's needs, EWH works with a local educational institution and Ministry of Health to train BMETs to international standards, train local teachers to carry on the program in the long term, and establish a permanent, accredited BMET training program.
The first BMET Training program began in Rwanda, and has since placed trained BMETs in every district in the country. Thanks to further funding from the GE Foundation, EWH has completed a training program [[Honduras]] and turned it over to local leadership, and, as of 2016, is training BMETs in Cambodia,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://1technation.com/cambodia-revisited-philip-camillocci-continues-to-help-developing-nation/|title=Cambodia Revisited: Philip Camillocci continues to help developing nation|date=2016-01-19|website=TechNation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref> [[Nigeria]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20140507005817/en/GE-Foundation-Duke-University-World-Healthcare-Tech#.U71gYrHGDMI|title=GE Foundation, Duke University World Healthcare Tech Lab, and Engineering World Health Establish Biomedical Equipment Training Program in Nigeria to Build Skills and Improve Capacity {{!}} Business Wire|website=www.businesswire.com|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref> and [[Ethiopia]].
==Chapters==
Engineering World Health has student chapters at 45 universities around the world. These Chapters engage students in activities as design projects for the developing world, biomedical equipment repair and evaluation, and raising awareness of [[global health]] challenges. Chapters may also get involved in the EWH Design Competition in which teams of engineering students submit a design directed at the needs of developing country healthcare.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.engr.utexas.edu/news/8036-students-create-patient-monitor|title=Students Use Makerspace Resources to Create Award-Winning Patient Monitor - Cockrell School of Engineering|last=Lee|first=Adrienne|website=www.engr.utexas.edu|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref> The top three teams are selected by an independent panel of judges and are then rewarded with cash prizes, giving them a chance to implement their device.
==BMET Library==
In 2016, EWH launched an open-source [[digital library]] for BMETs, with the goal of facilitating and fostering information exchange among engineers and technicians around the world. This library is a collection of open source books and publications containing information useful for training (BMETs), particularly in the developing countries where EWH is working.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://library.ewh.org/|title=BMET Digital Library|website=library.ewh.org|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ewh.org Engineering World Health official site]
