page.title: Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Lisbon

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}}
{{Infobox University |name = FFULisboa |native_name = Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Lisbon |image_name = LogoFFULisboa.png |motto = “By knowledge, by innovation” |established = 1836 |type = [[Public university|Public]] |city = [[Lisbon]] |country = [[Portugal]] |campus = University City of Lisbon |website = [http://www.ff.ulisboa.pt/ www.ff.ulisboa.pt] }}
The '''Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Lisbon''' (FFULisboa) is a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] public institution of higher education dedicated to education, research, knowledge transfer and continuing education in the fields of [[pharmacy]], medicine, and [[pharmaceutical sciences]].<ref name="FFULisboa">{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/faculdade/apresentacao/|title=Faculty – Presentation|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref>
The FFULisboa is a recognized institution at the national and international level. The courses that grant an academic degree are accredited by the Agency for Assessment and Accreditation of Higher Education (A3ES)<ref name=A3ES>{{cite web|URL=http://www.a3es.pt/pt/acreditacao-e-auditoria/resultados-dos-processos-de-acreditacao/acreditacao-de-ciclos-de-estudos|title=Cycles of Studies Accreditation|publisher=A3ES}}</ref> and the Integrated Master in Pharmaceutical Sciences is also accredited by the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society (Ordem dos Farmacêuticos) for professional practice.<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ordemfarmaceuticos.pt/scid//ofWebStd_1/defaultCategoryViewOne.asp?categoryId=1908|title=Pharmaceutical Education|author=Fernando Ramos|publisher=Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society}}</ref>
With the motto, "By knowledge, by innovation," the FFULisboa takes an active role in the dissemination within the field of Pharmaceutical Sciences<ref name="FFULisboa"/> and further activities addressed to the community regarding [[public health]]. Promoting a culture of internationalization, it is associated to many of its academic counterparts and other relevant national and international institutions, in educational and scientific projects, exchange programs and other partnerships.<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/a-ulisboa-na-promocao-da-saude-infantil/|title=ULisboa in the Promotion of Children's Health|date=30 May 2016|publisher=FFULisboa|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/estudantes-da-ffulisboa-colaboram-em-projeto-de-sensibilizacao-solar/|title=FFULisboa students collaborate on solar awareness project|date=16 May 2016|publisher=FFULisboa|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref>
== History == [[File:Raul Hestnes Fereira Faculdade de FarmáciaLisboa 3921.jpg|thumb|Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Lisbon]] The Faculty of Pharmacy of the [[University of Lisbon]] was born in 1836 as a School of Pharmacy integrated in the Medical-Surgical School of [[Lisbon]], in which the teaching in the field of pharmacy was assumed by the apothecary of St Joseph's Hospital. With the establishment of the University of Lisbon in March 1911, the School of Pharmacy remained attached to the same institution, now known as Faculty of Medicine of the University of Lisbon.<ref name="História">{{cite web|URL=http://www.monumentos.pt/site/app_pagesuser/sipa.aspx?id=30913|title=Facilities of the Faculty of Pharmacy of the University of Lisbon|publisher=Information System for Architectural Heritage}}</ref>
By Decree No. 4653 of July 14, 1918, it gained autonomy and was named as the Pharmacy School of the University of Lisbon.<ref>{{cite web|URL=https://dre.pt/application/dir/pdfgratis/1918/07/15702.pdf|title=Decree No. 4653 of July 14, 1918|publisher=Diary of the Portuguese Government}}</ref> It continued, however, to share the facilities of the Faculty of Medicine, in a precarious and inadequate situation. Quinta da Torrinha was bought in 1920 to resolve this situation and to build its own facilities. It would be from this former farm that later the Campus (Cidade Universitária) would be created.<ref name="História"/>
In 1921, by Decree No. 7238 of January 18, the School gets the status of the Faculty of Pharmacy of the University of Lisbon and assigns bachelor and doctoral degrees in pharmacy.<ref>{{cite web|URL=https://dre.pt/application/file/362576|title=Decree No. 7238 of January 18, 1921|publisher=Diary of the Portuguese Government}}</ref> In 1932, it was extinguished along with its counterpart of [[Coimbra]], giving way again to a Superior School of Pharmacy, which only granted a bachelor's degree; only in the [[University of Porto]] the Faculty of Pharmacy has remained, where were also given the degrees of graduate ("licenciado") and doctor. This would only be reversed in 1968, when it was restored the Pharmacy Faculties of Coimbra and Lisbon, placing them on an equal footing with the [[Porto]] academy.<ref name="História"/>
Today, the FFULisboa teaches various curricular units, some of them in hospital environment. Through these, and project curricular units, students are offered a direct relationship interaction with the pharmaceutical [[profession]] as well as with the scientific research that is carried out at the faculty's Research Units.<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/faculdade/historia/|title=Faculty – History|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref>
== Education == FFULisboa provides courses covering all higher education cycles by integrating different areas associated with the professional performance of pharmacists and scientific development in the field of pharmaceutical sciences.<ref name="FFULisboa"/>
=== Integrated Master in Pharmaceutical Sciences === This course enables the [[Master's degree|Master]] in pharmaceutical sciences for qualified professional practice, recognized by the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society, including the following activities:<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/Mestrado-Integrado-em-Ci%C3%AAnciasFarmac%C3%AAuticas.pdf|title=Integrated Master in Pharmaceutical Sciences|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Design, discovery, development, manufacturing and usage of human or veterinary medicines and medical devices. *Research and development in the field of Pharmaceutical Sciences. *Education programs addressed to the community in the context of health promotion, disease prevention and healthy aging. *Pharmaceutical practice and pharmaceutical care. *[[Biological]] sample collection, execution and technical and biopathological validation of [[clinical chemistry|clinical]] analysis. *[[Toxicology]], water and food science.
'''Course outline:'''
*Duration: 10 semesters (5 years) | [[ECTS grading scale|ECTS]]: 300 - Nine semesters of multidisciplinary training + one semester of internship and public discussion of a monograph. After six semesters the degree of bachelor in Basic Studies of Pharmaceutical Sciences is conferred upon approval of 180 ECTS.<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/PlanoEstudosMICF2007.pdf|title=Dispatch no. 3816, of March 2, 2010|publisher=Diary of the Portuguese Government}}</ref>
The Integrated Master in Pharmaceutical Sciences of FFULisboa is accredited by the Agency for Assessment and Accreditation of Higher Education and the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society,<ref name=A3ES/> enabling the practice in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/FOLHETO_FFUL2016.pdf|title=Integrated Master in Pharmaceutical Sciences 2016|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref>
=== Masters === *Laboratory Medicine<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/mestrados/cursos/mestrado-em-analises-clinicas/|title=Education – Masters – Courses – Master in Laboratory Medicine|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Biopharmaceutical Sciences<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/mestrados/cursos/mestrado-em-ciencias-biofarmaceuticas/|title=Education – Masters – Courses – Master in Biopharmaceutical Sciences|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Pharmaceutical Engineering (in association with the [[Instituto Superior Técnico]] of the University of Lisbon)<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/mestrados/cursos/engenharia-farmaceutica/|title=Education – Masters – Courses – Master in Pharmaceutical Engineering|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Pharmaceutical Intervention and Therapeutic Management<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/mestrados/cursos/mestrado-em-intervencao-farmaceutica-e-gestao-da-terapeutica/|title=Education – Masters – Courses – Master in Pharmaceutical Intervention and Therapeutic Management|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Food Quality and Health<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/mestrados/cursos/mestrado-em-qualidade-alimentar-saude/|title=Education – Masters – Courses – Master in Food Quality and Health|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Pharmaceutical and Medicinal Chemistry<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/mestrados/cursos/mestrado-em-quimica-farmaceutica-e-terapeutica-2/|title=Education – Masters – Courses – Master in Pharmaceutical and Medicinal Chemistry|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Regulation and Evaluation of Medicines and Health Products<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/mestrados/cursos/regulacao-e-avaliacao-de-medicamentos-e-produtos-de-saude/|title=Education – Masters – Courses – Master in Regulation and Evaluation of Medicines and Health Products|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref>
=== Doctorate in Pharmacy === Supported by several doctoral programmes, such as: * PhD Programme in Medicines and Pharmaceutical Innovation (i3DU) (in association with the [[University of Porto]])<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/doutoramento-em-farmacia/i3du/|title=Education – Doctorate in Pharmacy – i3DU|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> * Medical Biochemistry and Biophysics Doctoral Programme (M2B-PhD) (in association with the [[University of Coimbra]] and the University of Porto)<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/doutoramento-em-farmacia/m2b-phd/|title=Education – Doctorate in Pharmacy – M2B-PhD|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> * PhD Program in Integrative Neuroscience of the University of Lisbon (NeurULisboa)<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/doutoramento-em-farmacia/neurulisboa/|title=Education – Doctorate in Pharmacy – NeurULisboa|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> * Medicinal Chemistry PhD Programme (MedChemTrain) (in association with the Faculty of Sciences, Faculty of Medicine, Faculty of Psychology and Instituto Superior Técnico of the University of Lisbon)<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/doutoramento-em-farmacia/medchemtrain/|title=Education – Doctorate in Pharmacy – MedChemTrain|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> * Doctoral Programme Advanced Integrated Microsystems (AIM) (in association with the Instituto Superior Técnico of the University of Lisbon and [[Universidade Nova de Lisboa]])<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ensino/doutoramento-em-farmacia/aim/|title=Education – Doctorate in Pharmacy – AIM|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref>
== Departments == Since 2016, the FFULisboa has included the following departments in its organizational structure: * [[Biochemistry]] and Human Biology<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/bbh/|title= Biochemistry and Human Biology Department|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *[[Pharmacological]] Sciences<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/cf/|title= Pharmacological Sciences Department|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Toxicological and [[Bromatological]] Sciences<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ctb/|title= Toxicological and Bromatological Sciences Department|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Pharmaceutics and Pharmaceutical Technology<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/fgtf/|title= Pharmaceutics and Pharmaceutical Technology Department|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *[[Microbiology]] and [[Immunology]]<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/mi/|title= Microbiology and Immunology Department|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Pharmaceutical and Medicinal Chemistry<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/qft/|title= Pharmaceutical and Medicinal Chemistry Department|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Social Pharmacy<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/sf/|title= Social Pharmacy Department|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref>
== Research == Scientific research in FFULisboa is ensured by the Research Institute for Medicines ([http://imed.ulisboa.pt/ iMed.ULisboa]) which integrates more than 200 researchers, focusing its activity in four main areas, the so-called 3DU:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://imed.ulisboa.pt/research/program-areas/| title=iMed.ULisboa {{!}} Program Areas|accessdate=2016-08-19|work=imed.ulisboa.pt}}</ref> *Discovery of therapeutic targets *Design of new molecules *Pharmaceutical development *Rational use of Medicines The iMed.ULisboa has 15 research groups working on basic and translational research in the area of therapeutic innovation. This research institute encourages research across the spectrum of drug development, from laboratory to pre-clinical studies, promoting a response to scientific challenges in emerging areas, such as aging and related diseases, [[diabetes]], [[cancer]], [[neurodegeneration]], osteoarticular degeneration, [[inflammation|inflammatory]], [[infectious]] and [[metabolic diseases]].
The research involves collaborations with various universities, research centers, hospitals, pharmaceutical industry, national and international regulatory agencies in the Medicines area.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://imed.ulisboa.pt/advanced-training/| title=iMed.ULisboa {{!}} Advanced Training|accessdate=2016-08-19|work=imed.ulisboa.pt}}</ref> It has been fostering the realization of scientific projects, financially supported at national and international level. The results and the teams have been internationally recognized and awarded.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://imed.ulisboa.pt/news-and-events/news/| title=iMed.ULisboa {{!}} News|accessdate=2016-08-19|work=imed.ulisboa.pt}}</ref>
In the context of research and teaching, FFULisboa invests in interdisciplinary partnerships with other Schools of ULisboa in order to develop new cross-cutting areas of knowledge, participating in important networks,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ff.ul.pt/investigacao/redes-ulisboa/| title=Networks of the University of Lisbon – Faculty of Pharmacy|access-date=2016-08-19|language=pt-PT}}</ref> such as: *[http://www.colegiof3.ulisboa.pt/ College “Food, Farming & Forestry (F3)”] *[http://colegiomente-cerebro.ulisboa.pt/ College Mind-Brain] *AGRO network *SEA network *MOV network *Health network *tEP network *VALUE network
== Community Services == The FFULisboa provides to the general public, as well as public and private entities, a number of specialized services that result from the application of [[translational research]] performed at the school in the clinical, instrumental and industrial context, including: *Animal facilities<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/bioterio/|title=Animal facilities|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Instrumental [[laboratory]]<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/blocoinstrumental/|title=Instrumental laboratory|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Clinical [[biochemistry]] and [[microbiology]] laboratory<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/lac/|title=Clinical biochemistry and microbiology laboratory|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *Structural Analysis Laboratory<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/lem/|title=Structural Analysis Laboratory|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref> *The [[Pharmacovigilance]] Unit of Southern Portugal<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/ufs/|title=The Pharmacovigilance Unit of Southern Portugal|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref>
== Awards and Distinctions == The FFULisboa has been awarded in 2013 with the Medal of Honor of the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ulisboa.pt/faculdade-de-farmacia-recebe-medalha-de-honra-da-ordem-dos-farmaceuticos/|title=Faculty of Pharmacy receives Medal of Honor of the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society|date=27 September 2013|publisher=ULisboa|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref>
== International cooperation == To strengthen the internationalization of teaching and scientific research, FFULisboa cooperates with similar institutions and various agencies and entities in the mobility and training of students, teachers and researchers.<ref name=Internationalization>{{cite web|URL=http://www.ff.ul.pt/internacional/cooperacao-estrategica/|title=International – Strategic Cooperation|publisher=FFULisboa}}</ref>
In the context of an international scientific policy, FFULisboa maintains partnerships with foreign consortiums to attract graduate students and get competitive funding.<ref name=Internationalization/>
Strategic cooperation encourages the development, innovation, internationalization and the [[attractiveness]] of the institution with students, teachers and international researchers. The FFULisboa participates in international programs and integrates international research networks.<ref name=Internationalization/> *[http://www.safescimet.eu/ IMI SafeSciMET] *[http://spiralconnect.univ-lyon1.fr/webapp/website/website.html?id=5431768 EUDIPharm] *[https://www.eacr.org/ European Association for Cancer Research (EACR)] *[http://www.eufeps.org/ European Federation for Pharmaceutical Sciences (EUFEPS)] *[http://eafponline.eu/ European Association of Faculties of Pharmacy (EAFP)] *[http://www.esf.org/home.html European Science Foundation (ESF)] *[https://www.imi.europa.eu/ Innovative Medicines Initiative (IMI)] *[http://eithealth.eu/ European Institute of Innovation & Technology (EIT Health)] *[http://www.coiffa.org.mx/ Conferencia Iberoamericana de Facultades de Farmacia (COIFFA)]
== Personalities associated with the Faculty == *Alberto Ralha (1921-2010) - Academic and politician; President of the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society (1980-1983); Secretary of State for Higher Education.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://expresso.sapo.pt/sociedade/morreu-alberto-ralha-ex-secretario-de-estado-do-ensino-superior=f555718|title=Alberto Ralha, former Secretary of State for Higher Education, has died|date=3 January 2010|publisher=Expresso|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Aluísio Marques Leal (1915-2016) - Director of Pharmaceutical Services of the University Hospital of Santa Marta, where he collaborated with the Nobel Laureate [[Egas Moniz]] in his research; First Technical Director of Pharmaceutical Services of the Hospital of Santa Maria; Professor of Hospital Pharmacy in FFULisboa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ordemfarmaceuticos.pt/scid/ofWebInst_09/defaultArticleViewOne.asp?articleID=4021&categoryID=1492|title=Aluísio Marques Leal celebrates his 95th birthday|publisher=Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Álvaro Teixeira Lopes - Director of the [[Forensic Science]] Laboratory of the [[Polícia Judiciária]] (2008-2009).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtp.pt/noticias/pais/alvaro-teixeira-lopes-e-o-novo-director-do-laboratorio-da-policia-cientifica-da-pj_a194638|title=Álvaro Teixeira Lopes is the new director of the forensic science laboratory of PJ|date=4 March 2008|publisher=Antena 1|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Ana Paula Martins – President of the Pharmaceutical Society since 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://economico.sapo.pt/noticias/ana-paula-martins-eleita-nova-bastonaria-da-ordem-dos-farmaceuticos_241961.html|title=Ana Paula Martins elected new President of the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society|date=7 February 2016|publisher=Económico|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Beatriz Lima - Academic; President of the Scientific Committee of the Innovative Medicines Initiative (IMI), since 2014; President of the Human Medicinal Products Safety Committee of the [[European Medicines Agency]] (EMA) (2001-2012).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ulisboa.pt/professora-beatriz-lima-nomeada-para-o-comite-do-imi/|title=Professor Beatriz Lima appointed for the IMI Committee|date=16 September 2013|publisher=ULisboa|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Bruno Sepodes - Chairman of the Committee for Orphan Medicinal Products of the European Medicines Agency (EMA) since 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ordemfarmaceuticos.pt/scid/ofWebInst_09/defaultArticleViewOne.asp?categoryID=1492&articleID=5964|title=Bruno Sepodes takes on presidency of the Committee for Orphan Medicinal Products of EMA|date=14 September 2012|publisher=Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Carlos Fernando Costa da Silveira (1923-) – Academic, scientist and navy officer; President of the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society (1989-1995); National Health Award (2010); Gold Medal of the Order of Pharmacists (2012).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ordemfarmaceuticos.pt/scid/ofWebInst_09/defaultArticleViewOne.asp?categoryID=1492&articleID=3523|title=President Carlos Silveira receives National Health Award|date=7 April 2010|publisher=Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Elisabete Faria - interim President of the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society (2008-2009).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://expresso.sapo.pt/actualidade/ordem-dos-farmaceuticos-tem-novo-bastonario=f543322|title=The Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society has a new President|date=23 October 2010|publisher=Expresso|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Helder Mota Filipe - President of National Authority of Medicines and Health Products (INFARMED) in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ordemfarmaceuticos.pt/scid/ofWebInst_09/defaultArticleViewOne.asp?categoryID=1492&articleID=10173|title=Helder Mota Filipe takes on presidency of Infarmed|date=6 November 2015|publisher=Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *João Silveira - President of the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society (1995-2001).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ordemfarmaceuticos.pt/scid/ofWebInst_09/defaultArticleViewOne.asp?categoryID=1492&articleID=6438|title=President and Board took office|publisher=Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *José Guimarães Morais – Academic and scientist; Emeritus Professor; Director of FFULisboa (2009-2012); President of the Executive Council of FFULisboa (1996-2009); President of the Medicines Evaluation Committee INFARMED (1992-2009); President of the Portuguese Society of Pharmaceutical Sciences (2005-2011); Gold Medal of the [[Ministry of Health]] (2009); Medal of Honor of the Order of Pharmacists (2010); Alumni Distinguished Lifetime Achievement Award from the [[University of Michigan]] (2013); Grand Officer of the Order of Public Instruction (2015).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justnews.pt/noticias/jose-guimaraes-morais-e-joao-cordeiro-recebem-medalhas-de-ouro-da-ordem-dos-farmaceuticos#.V6TENrgrLIU|title=José Guimarães Morais and João Cordeiro receive Medal of Honor of the Order of Pharmacists|date=10 November 2015|publisher=Just News|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *José de Sousa Martins (1843-1897) - Pharmacist, medical doctor and Professor at the Medical-Surgical School of Lisbon. *Manuel Rodrigues de Carvalho (1929-1999) - Pharmacist and army officer; Minister of Education and Culture (1974-1975). *Odette Ferreira (1925-2018) – Academic and scientist in the field of [[microbiology]], identified the type 2 [[HIV]]; Chevalier de l'[[Ordre des Palmes Académiques]] (1975); Chevalier de l'[[Ordre national de la Légion d'honneur]] (1987); Commander of the [[Military Order of Saint James of the Sword]] (1988); Medal of Honor of the Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society (1989); Medal of Honor of the [[Complutense University of Madrid]] (1995); Prize Universidade de Lisboa (2006).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.publico.pt/sociedade/noticia/odette-ferreira-a-mulher-que-a-investigacao-da-sida-ajudou-a-mudar-antes-era-uma-betinha-1678762|title=Odette Ferreira, the woman who AIDS research helped to change|author=Alexandra Campos|date=9 December 2014|publisher=Público|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Pedro Augusto Franco (1833-1902) - Pharmacist; 1st Earl of Restelo; Peer of the realm; Mayor of Belém; Councillor and Mayor of Lisbon (1894-1897 and 1899-1901). *Rogerio Gaspar - Vice-Rector of ULisboa (2013-2016); President of the Portuguese Society of Pharmaceutical Sciences, since 2016; Academic Foreign Correspondent of the Royal National Academy of Pharmacy Spain since 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://justnews.pt/noticias/rogerio-gaspar-e-o-novo-presidente-da-sociedade-portuguesa-de-ciencias-farmaceuticas/#.V6TJ2LgrLIU|title=Rogério Gaspar is the new President of the Portuguese Society of Pharmaceutical Sciences|date=14 March 2016|publisher=Just News|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Rui Santos Ivo - Pharmacist; President of the International Federation of Pharmaceutical Students (IPSF) (1986-1987); President of INFARMED (2002-2005); President of the Central Administration of the Health System (ACSS) (2014-2016).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ionline.sapo.pt/304583|title=Rui Ivo is the new President of the Central Administration of the Health System|date=25 September 2014|publisher=i|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref>
== Doctors Honoris Causa == *James Nicholas Iley (2014) – Senior Lecturer of the [[Open University]], UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.publico.pt/educacao/noticia/fraga-iribarne-doutor-honoris-causa-da-universidade-de-lisboa-1208102|title=Fraga Iribarne doctor "honoris causa" of the University of Lisbon|date=10 November 2004|publisher=Público|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Zachary Leslie Benet (2016) – Professor at the [[University of California]], San Francisco, [[United States of America|United States]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsfarma.pt/noticias/3853-ulisboa-atribui-doutoramento-honoris-causa-ao-professor-leslie-benet.html|title=ULisboa awarded Doctor Honoris Causa to Professor Leslie Benet|date=11 May 2016|publisher=NewsFarma|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> *Marinus Durand (2005) – Professor at the [[Universiteit van Amsterdam]], Netherlands. *Michael Drummond (2015) – Professor at the [[University of York]], UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ordemfarmaceuticos.pt/scid/ofWebInst_09/defaultArticleViewOne.asp?categoryID=1492&articleID=9442|title=University of Lisbon awarded honoris causa to Michael Drummond|date=8 May 2015|publisher=Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> * Sir [[Richard John Roberts]] (2012) – [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] 1993.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ordemfarmaceuticos.pt/scid/ofWebInst_09/defaultArticleViewOne.asp?categoryID=1492&articleID=6095|title=New UL PhDs from the Health Sciences area received diplomas|date=19 October 2012|publisher=Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|25em}}
== External links == {{Div col}} *[http://www.ff.ul.pt/ Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Lisbon] *[http://imed.ulisboa.pt/ Research Institute for Medicines - iMed.ULisboa] *[http://www.aefful.pt/ Students Association of the Faculty of Pharmacy of the Universidade de Lisboa (AEFFUL)] *[http://www.ulisboa.pt/ University of Lisbon] *[http://www.ordemfarmaceuticos.pt/ Portuguese Pharmaceutical Society (Ordem dos Farmacêuticos)] *[http://www.infarmed.pt/ National Authority of Medicines and Health Products (INFARMED)] *[http://www.anf.pt/ National Association of Pharmacies (ANF)] *[http://www.portaldasfarmacias.com/ Portuguese Association of Pharmacies (AFP)] *[http://www.apifarma.pt/ Portuguese Association of the Pharmaceutical Industry (APIFARMA)] *[http://www.apfh.pt/ Portuguese Association of Hospital Pharmacists (APFH)] *[http://www.apef.pt/ Portuguese Association of Pharmacy Students (APEF)] *[http://eafponline.eu/ European Association of Faculties of Pharmacy (EAFP)] *[http://coiffa.org.mx/ Conferencia Iberoamericana de Facultades de Farmacia (COIFFA)] *[http://www.eufeps.org/ European Federation for Pharmaceutical Sciences (EUFEPS)] *[https://www.eacr.org/ European Association for Cancer Research (EACR)] *[http://www.esf.org/ European Science Foundation (ESF)] *[http://www.epsa-online.org/ European Pharmaceutical Students Association (EPSA)] *[https://www.imi.europa.eu/ Innovative Medicines Initiative (IMI)] *[https://eit.europa.eu/eit-community/eit-health/ EIT Health - European Institute of Innovation & Technology] {{Div col end}}

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Campaign to motivate and mobilize people around the world to improve their handwashing habits" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Campaign to motivate and mobilize people around the world to improve their handwashing habits}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Global Handwashing Day |type = international |image = Global Handwashing Day (emblem).jpg |imagesize = |caption = Logo used for Global Handwashing Day around the world. Shown in the image are water, soap, and hand. |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = |begins = |ends = |date = 15 October |scheduling = same day each year |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |celebrations ="Our hands, our future!" |observances = |relatedto = [[Menstrual hygiene day]] |firsttime = 15 October 2008 }}
'''Global Handwashing Day''' ('''GHD''') is a campaign to motivate and mobilize people around the [[world]] to improve their [[Hand washing|handwashing]] habits. Washing hands at critical points during the day and washing with [[soap]] are both important.
Global Handwashing Day occurs on 15 October of each year. The global campaign is dedicated to raising awareness of handwashing with soap as a key factor in [[Preventive healthcare|disease prevention]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nfh&AN=20091015004104007&site=ehost-live|title = Lae Marks Global Handwashing Day|last = Rai|first = Frank|date = 12 August 2009|work = Post-Courier (Papua New Guinea)|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = Newspaper Source – EBSCO}}</ref> Respiratory and intestinal diseases can be reduced by 25-50%.
==Implementation and management== The Global Handwashing Partnership (GHP) (formerly called "[[Public-private partnership|Public Private Partnership]] for Handwashing" (PPPHW)) established Global Handwashing Day in 2008 as a way to promote a global and local vision of handwashing with soap.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=12 October 2012|title=Global Handwashing Day|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=82513752&site=ehost-live|journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|volume=61|issue=40|page=821|doi=|pmid=|access-date=24 July 2015|subscription=yes}}</ref>
Steering Committee members of the GHP include Colgate-Palmolive; FHI 360; The London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine; Procter & Gamble; UNICEF; Unilever; University at Buffalo; USAID; the Water and Sanitation Programme at the World Bank; and the Water Supply and Sanitation Collaborative Council.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalhandwashing.org/about-us/who-we-are/|title=The Global Handwashing Partnership|website=globalhandwashing.org}}</ref>
Continued research on handwashing habits and practices is commissioned in conjunction with GHD. In 2011, [[Svenska Cellulosa Aktiebolaget]] (SCA), sponsored a study to assess the handwashing habits of American and Canadian adults, finding that many were not using soap when washing their hands.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bwh&AN=bizwire.c37268574&site=ehost-live|title = New Research Reveals Poor Handwashing Practices|last = |first = |date = 14 October 2011|work = Business Wire|access-date = 10 August 2015|via = Regional Business News – EBSCOhost}}</ref>
===Aims=== The aims of Global Handwashing Day are to:<ref name=":1" /> * Foster and support a general culture of handwashing with soap in all societies * Shine a spotlight on the state of handwashing in each country * Raise awareness about the benefits of handwashing with soap.
==Activities== Each year, over 200 million people celebrate Global Handwashing Day.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://concern-universal.org/get-involved/campaigns-appeals/global-handwashing-day/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208100034/http://concern-universal.org/get-involved/campaigns-appeals/global-handwashing-day |archivedate=8 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Examples=== *On 15 October 2014, [[Madhya Pradesh]] won the [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Record]] for the most massive handwashing program.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url = http://www.hindustantimes.com/bhopal/mp-creates-world-record-for-mass-hand-washing-initiative-guinness-book-acknowledges-feat/article1-1365615.aspx|title = MP Creates World Record for Mass Handwashing Initiative; Guinness Book Acknowledges Feat|last = |first = |date = 3 July 2015|work = Hindustan Times|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref> There were 1,276,425 children in 51 different districts participating.<ref name=":0" /> *Sometimes, groups choose to celebrate GHD on other dates than 15 October. In [[Ethiopia]], 300 people celebrated Global Handwashing Day in [[Addis Ababa]] on 1 November in 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://unicefethiopia.wordpress.com/2013/11/04/ethiopia-celebrates-global-handwashing-day/|title = Ethiopia Celebrates Global Handwashing Day|last = Bizuwork|first = Demissew|date = 4 November 2013|work = UNICEF Ethiopia|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = }}</ref> * On 15 October 2015, Lupok Central Elementary School, Guiuan Eastern Samar, Philippines celebrated the Global Handwashing Day by doing the proper handwashing before starting classes.
==History== Global Handwashing Day was initiated by the Global Handwashing Partnership (GHP) in August 2008 at the annual [[World Water Week]] in Stockholm, Sweden.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://globalhandwashing.org/about-us/our-history/|title = The Global Public Private Partnership for Handwashing – Our History|date = |accessdate = 18 December 2015|website = The Global Public Private Partnership for Handwashing|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> This means that the first Global Handwashing Day took place on 15 October 2008. The date was appointed by the UN General Assembly. The year 2008 was also the [[International Year of Sanitation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.who.int/gpsc/events/2008/15_10_08/en/index.html|title = Global Handwashing Day|date = 15 October 2008|accessdate = 24 July 2015|website = World Health Organization|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The founding bodies in 2008 included: FHI360 (a nonprofit human development organization based in the US),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fhi360.org/about-us|title=fhi360 About Us|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=fhi360|accessdate=11 August 2015}}</ref> [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]], [[Procter & Gamble]], [[UNICEF]], [[Unilever]], [[Water and sanitation program|World Bank Water & Sanitation Program]] and the [[United States Agency for International Development]].
===Themes=== *The focus for Global Handwashing Day's inaugural year in 2008 was school children. In that year, the members pledged to get the maximum number of school children handwashing with soap in more than 70 countries. In [[India]] in 2008, [[cricket]] legend [[Sachin Tendulkar]] and his teammates joined an estimated 100 million schoolchildren around the country in lathering up for better health and hygiene as part of the first Global Handwashing Day.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/india_45974.html|title = Star Cricketer Sachin Tendulkar Promotes Handwashing in India|last = Walker|first = Angela|date = 16 October 2008|work = UNICEF|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = }}</ref> *In 2014, Global Handwashing Day was used as an opportunity to fight Ebola.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.unicef.org/media/media_76267.html|title = Handwashing One Important Tool in the Ebola Fight|last = |first = |date = 15 October 2014|work = UNICEF|access-date = 10 August 2015|via = }}</ref> In Nigeria, for example, Concern Universal and Carex sponsored events featuring singer Sunny Neji.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://concern-universal.org/get-involved/campaigns-appeals/global-handwashing-day/|title = Global Handwashing Day: Handwashing Saves Lives|date = |accessdate = 10 August 2015|website = Concern Universal Nigeria|publisher = |last = |first = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150208100034/http://concern-universal.org/get-involved/campaigns-appeals/global-handwashing-day|archivedate = 8 February 2015}}</ref> *Theme for Global Handwashing Day, 2018: Clean hands - a recipe for health.[https://globalhandwashing.org]
Theme for Global Handwashing Day 2018: Clean Hands- a recipe for health
== Background == [[File:Global Handwashing Day Celebration at Lupok Central Elementary School, Guiuan Eastern Samar Philippines.png|thumb| Pupils of Lupok Central Elementary School Guiuan Eastern Samar, [[Philippines]] during the Global Hand Washing Day Celebration in 2015.]]
[[File:Global Handwashing Day 2008 celebrations with celebrities at City Central School (Cagayan de Oro) (3171506141).jpg|thumb|Global Handwashing Day 2008 celebrations with celebrities at City Central School in Cagayan de Oro, Philippines.]]
[[File:Dry run with kids at City Central School CDO on how to wash hands with soap during Global Handwashing Day 2008 (Cagayan de Oro) (3172335900).jpg|thumb|Dry run with kids at City Central School in Cagayan de Oro on how to wash hands with soap during Global Handwashing Day 2008 (Philippines)]]
[[File:GHWWSD.JPG|thumb|Global handwashing day celebrations in Indonesia in 2008]]
The campaign was initiated to reduce childhood mortality rates and related [[respiratory]] and [[Diarrhea|diarrheal diseases]] by introducing simple [[Behaviour change (public health)|behavioral changes]], such as [[handwashing]] with [[soap]]. This simple action can reduce the [[mortality rate]] of respiratory disease by 25%. Death from diarrheal diseases can be reduced by 50%.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Curtis|first1=Val|last2=Cairncross|first2=Sandy|date=May 2003|title=Effect of washing hands with soap on diarrhoea risk in the community: a systematic review|journal=The Lancet Infectious Diseases|volume=3|issue=5|pages=275–281|doi=10.1016/S1473-3099(03)00606-6|pmid=12726975}}</ref> Across the world, more than 60 percent of health workers do not adhere to proper hand hygiene. According to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, US health care providers, on average, wash their hands less than half of the time they should. On any given day, one in 25 US hospital patients has at least one health care-associated infection.<ref name="CDC">{{cite web |title=Hand Hygiene in Healthcare Settings |url=https://www.cdc.gov/handhygiene/index.html |website=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention |publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Division of Healthcare Quality Promotion (DHQP) |accessdate=23 October 2018 |date=May 3, 2018}}</ref>
=== Importance of handwashing === {{Main article|Handwashing}} {{tone|section|date=April 2018}} Handwashing with soap is very effective and the least expensive way to prevent [[diarrhea]] and [[acute respiratory infection]]s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nfh&AN=6FI3204107250&site=ehost-live|title=MOH Celebrates Global Handwashing Day|last=|first=|date=15 October 2009|work=Arabia 2000|access-date=24 July 2015|via=Newspaper Source – EBSCO}}</ref> [[Pneumonia]], a major ARI (acute respiratory infection), is the number one cause of mortality among children under five years old, killing an estimated 1.8 million children per year. [[Diarrhea]] and pneumonia together account for almost 3.5 million child deaths annually.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/publications/files/The_State_of_the_Worlds_Children_2008.pdf|title=The State of the World’s Children 2008. Child Survival. UNICEF|publisher=}}</ref> Handwashing with soap is estimated to reduce cases of diarrhea by 30% and respiratory infections by 21% in children under the age of five.<ref name=":1" />
It is important to make handwashing into a [[habit]]. Good handwashing with soap before [[eating]] and after using the toilet into a regular habit can save more lives than any single [[vaccine]] or medical intervention, cutting deaths from diarrhea by almost half and deaths from acute [[respiratory infection]]s by one-quarter.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://foodpoisoningbulletin.com/2013/today-is-global-handwashing-day/|title=Today is Global Handwashing Day|last=Larsen|first=Linda|date=15 October 2013|work=Food Poisoning Bulletin|access-date=24 July 2015|via=}}</ref>
Handwashing is usually done together with other [[sanitation]] interventions as part of water, sanitation and hygiene [[WASH]] programmes.
The Global Handwashing Day helps raise awareness of the importance of washing with soap, but it also makes it fun for children to get involved.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bwh&AN=wapo.ea30fbe0-e86a-11e0-8a05-c10ec107dc66&site=ehost-live|title=Getting All Lathered Up|last=Sawyer|first=Kem Knapp|date=10 October 2011|work=The Washington Post|access-date=24 July 2015|via=Regional Business News – EBSCO}}</ref>
Proper hygiene requires that individuals know the importance of good hygiene and develop the habits to carry it out. There are people with plenty of money but nonetheless, they lack the important habits of timely handwashing with soap, and thereby unknowingly endanger themselves and others around them.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/jeffrey-sachs/global-handwashing-day-in_b_5989280.html|title=Global Handwashing Day in the Time of Ebola|author=Jeffrey Sachs|author2=Myriam Sidibe|date=15 October 2014|publisher=Huffington Post}}</ref>
[[Peer pressure|Peer influence]] is significant to seeing increased handwashing among students. In a study conducted in [[Kenya]], researchers found that students were much more likely to wash their hands when another student is present.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pickering|first=Amy J.|last2=Blum|first2=Annalise G.|last3=Breiman|first3=Robert F.|last4=Ram|first4=Pavani K.|last5=Davis|first5=Jennifer|date=27 March 2014|title=Video Surveillance Captures Student Hand Hygiene Behavior, Reactivity to Observation, and Peer Influence in Kenyan Primary Schools|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0092571|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=9|issue=3|pages=e92571|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0092571|pmc=3968003|pmid=24676389}}</ref> Peer influence is only successful, however, when students know that handwashing is a desirable action.
=== Related awareness days === The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) celebrates a World Hand Hygiene Day on 5 May. In 2018 the theme was prevention of [[sepsis]] in health care.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/infection-prevention/campaigns/clean-hands/5may2018/en/|title=Infection prevention and control|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=World Health Organization|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=4 May 2018}}</ref> The theme of the year before was to combat [[Antimicrobial resistance|antibiotic resistance]] (AMR).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/infection-prevention/campaigns/clean-hands/2017/en/|title=Infection prevention and control|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=World Health Organization|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=4 May 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Behaviour change (public health)]] *[[Sanitation]] *[[Sustainable Sanitation Alliance]] *[[World Toilet Day]] *[[Menstrual hygiene day]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Global handwashing Day}} *[http://globalhandwashing.org Global Handwashing Partnership] *[http://globalhandwashing.org/global-handwashing-day/ Official site for Global Handwashing Day]

revision.text:
{{Globalize|date=May 2018}} '''Health care ratings''' are ratings or [[evaluation]]s of [[health care]]. In the United States they have been an increasingly used tool to try to drive accountability among [[Health_care_in_the_United_States#Providers|health care providers]] and in the context of classic [[Supply (economics)|supply]]/[[demand]] view of [[Health economics]], to help health care consumers make better choices.<ref name=Kolstad2009/>
Reviews in 2008 and 2009 review of research on the effects of health care ratings found that there was evidence that public ratings drove hospitals to improve their performance, but there was limited evidence that they affected how consumers choose health care providers or insurance plans, or that they changed the performance of individual doctors or insurance companies.<ref name=Kolstad2009>{{cite journal|last1=Kolstad|first1=JT|last2=Chernew|first2=ME|title=Quality and consumer decision making in the market for health insurance and health care services|journal=Medical Care Research and Review : MCRR|date=February 2009|volume=66|issue=1 Suppl|pages=28S–52S|doi=10.1177/1077558708325887|pmid=19029288}}</ref><ref name=Fung2008>{{cite journal|last=Fung|first=C.H.|title=Systematic Review: The Evidence That Publishing Patient Care Performance Data Improved Quality of Care|journal=Annals of Internal Medicine|year=2008|doi=10.7326/0003-4819-148-2-200801150-00006|pmid=18195336|volume=148|issue=2|pages=111–23|citeseerx=10.1.1.691.1541}} [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0026297/ DARE summary]</ref>
In may cases it is difficult to create health care ratings that can meaningfully summarize any individual provider's performance in a way that be compared with others', and data is often lacking with which to generate ratings.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sinaiko|first1=AD|last2=Eastman|first2=D|last3=Rosenthal|first3=MB|title=How report cards on physicians, physician groups, and hospitals can have greater impact on consumer choices|journal=Health Affairs (Project Hope)|date=March 2012|volume=31|issue=3|pages=602–11|doi=10.1377/hlthaff.2011.1197|pmid=22392672}}</ref>
People may have difficulty finding the ratings, especially if they are negative.<ref name=CampbellLaw>{{cite journal|last1=Madison|first1=Kristin|title=The Law and Policy of Health Care Quality Reporting |journal=Campbell Law Review|date=January 2009|volume=31|issue=2|pages=215–255|url=https://scholarship.law.campbell.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1481&context=clr}}</ref> To make these reports more accessible, large philanthropies, including the [[Robert Wood Johnson Foundation]], have funded major initiatives that are focused on performance measurement like the Aligning Forces for Quality program.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Casalino|first1=L. P.|last2=Elster|first2=A.|last3=Eisenberg|first3=A.|last4=Lewis|first4=E.|last5=Montgomery|first5=J.|last6=Ramos|first6=D.|title=Will Pay-For-Performance And Quality Reporting Affect Health Care Disparities?|journal=Health Affairs|date=1 May 2007|volume=26|issue=3|pages=w405–w414|doi=10.1377/hlthaff.26.3.w405|pmid=17426053}} {{open access}}</ref>
==See also== [[Health system#International comparisons|Health system international comparisons]]
