page.title: Reproductive health care for incarcerated women in the United States

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add pmc identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
In the United States, [[prison]]s are obligated to provide [[health care]] to [[prisoner]]s. Such health care is sometimes called ''[[correctional medicine]]''. In women's prisons, correctional medicine includes attention to [[reproductive health]].
The number of [[Incarceration of women in the United States|women incarcerated in the United States]] has increased greatly over the last few decades,{{specify|date=June 2016}} and at a faster rate than the number of incarcerated men.<ref name=":5" /> Many of the same factors that increase women's likelihood of incarceration also put them at a higher risk for contracting [[HIV/AIDS]] and other [[sexually transmitted infection]]s, and for having [[High-risk pregnancy|high-risk pregnancies]].<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Braithewaite|first=Ronald L.|last2=Treadwell|first2=Henrie M.|last3=Arriola|first3=Kimberly R J|date=2005|title=Health disparities and incarcerated women: a population ignored|pmc=1449417|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=95|issue=10|pages=1679–1681|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2005.065375|pmid=16186446}}</ref><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":8" /> The majority of incarcerated women are economically disadvantaged and poorly educated,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Maeve|first=M Katherine|date=1999|title=Adjudicated Health: Incarcerated Women and the Social Constructions of Health|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023%2FA%3A1008376229520|journal=Crime, Law and Social Change|volume=31|pages=49|doi=10.1023/A:1008376229520|pmid=|access-date=April 25, 2016}}</ref> and have not had adequate access to [[preventive healthcare]] prior to their imprisonment,<ref name=":11" /> such as [[Pap test]]s, [[STI test|STI screening]], and pregnancy counseling.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Clarke|first=Jennifer G.|last2=Hebert|first2=Megan R.|last3=Rosengard|first3=Cynthia|last4=Rose|first4=Jennifer S.|last5=DaSilva|first5=Kristen M.|last6=Stein|first6=Michael D.|date=2006|title=Reproductive Health Care and Family Flanning Feeds Among Incarcerated Women|pmc=1470599|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=96|issue=5|pages=834–839|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2004.060236|pmid=16571701}}</ref>
== Legal standards for health care availability == === Historical precedence ===
==== Estelle v. Gamble (1976) ==== [[Estelle v. Gamble]] obligates prisons to provide for the serious medical needs of their inmates.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8YdHAAAAMAAJ|title=The Incarcerated Woman: Rehabilitative Programming in Women's Prisons|last=Anderson|first=Tammy L.|date=2003|publisher=Prentice Hall|isbn=9780130940674|editor-last=Sharp|editor-first=Susan F.|pages=49–60|language=en|chapter=Issues in the availability of health care for women prisoners|editor-last2=Muraskin|editor-first2=Roslyn}}</ref> However, it also requires that an incarcerated person must demonstrate that they had a serious medical need, and that they didn't receive adequate medical care because officials showed "deliberate indifference." Due to the difficulty inherent in proving that a prison official knew about a medical condition, yet failed to respond to it, this standard makes it difficult to hold correctional facilities accountable for their mistakes.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5ekaWZJHfqMC|title=Our Bodies, Our Crimes: The Policing of Women’s Reproduction in America|last=Flavin|first=Jeanne|date=2008|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=9780814727553|language=en}}</ref>
==== Todaro v. Ward (1977) ==== Todaro v. Ward argued that women within a New York prison did not have adequate, constitutional access to healthcare. Since Todaro v. Ward was the first major court case that called into question incarcerated women's actual access to health care, it spurred organizations such as the American Medical Association, American Correctional Association, and the American Public Health Association to start creating standards for health care within prisons.<ref name=":0" />
==== Brown v. Beck (1980) ==== With this ruling, the court determined that the medical care provided to prisoners must only be "reasonable,"<ref name=":0" /> not necessarily "perfect, the best obtainable, or even very good."<ref name=":1" />
=== Relevant federal legislation and standards === Currently, no national agency monitors the treatment of prisoners, although a few governmental and non-governmental agencies do provide monitoring standards that facilities may use if they wish to become accredited (about thirty percent of prisons are accredited), and some federal legislation has been passed regarding correctional health care.<ref name=":7" />
==== Federal Prisoner Co-Payment Act (1999) ==== This legislation required that incarcerated individuals pay for some of their health care bill while in prison.<ref name=":0" />
==== Prison Litigation Reform Act (1996) ==== The [[Prison Litigation Reform Act]] made it much more difficult for prisoners to file class action and individual lawsuits against a prison.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Barry|first=Ellen M|date=2001|title=Bad Medicine: Health Care Inadequacies in Women's Prisons|url=http://uu5bm5kq6z.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info:sid/summon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Bad+medicine%3A+Health+care+inadequacies+in+women%27s+prisons&rft.jtitle=Criminal+Justice&rft.au=Ellen+M+Barry&rft.date=2001-04-01&rft.pub=American+Bar+Association&rft.issn=0887-7785&rft.volume=16&rft.issue=1&rft.spage=38&rft.externalDocID=73033132&paramdict=en-US|journal=Criminal Justice|doi=|pmid=|access-date=May 20, 2016}}</ref> The Prison Litigation Reform Act (PRLA) requires that prisoners exhaust a facility's own administrative resources and solutions before attempting to file a lawsuit. This can be detrimental because prisoners' health problems are often time-sensitive.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Roth|first=Rachel|date=2004|title=Searching for the State: Who Governs Prisoners' Reproductive Rights?|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/article/173809|journal=Social Politics: International Studies in Gender, State and Society|doi=|pmid=|access-date=May 24, 2016}}</ref> PRLA also includes a cap on attorney fees, which has made fewer attorneys willing to represent prisoners.<ref name=":1" /> Although PRLA applies to all lawsuits filed by incarcerated people, it is particularly relevant for women's health because most lawsuits filed by incarcerated women concern substandard health care.<ref name=":0" />
== Correctional reproductive health care ==
=== Pregnancy and prenatal care === As of 2005, about five to ten percent of incarcerated women were pregnant (most upon intake), and about 2,000 incarcerated women give birth every year.<ref name=":1" /> Incarcerated women already tend to have more high-risk pregnancies, due to possible complications by drug and alcohol abuse and STIs, histories of victimization and abuse, and poor support networks, so they are particularly in need of quality [[prenatal care]] as compared to non-incarcerated women.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Acoca|first=Leslie|date=January 1998|title=Defusing the Time Bomb: Understanding and Meeting the Growing Health Care Needs of Incarcerated Women in America|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?p=EAIM&u=mnalmgl&id=GALE|A20517103&v=2.1&it=r&sid=summon&userGroup=mnalmgl&authCount=1|journal=Crime and Delinquency|doi=|pmid=|access-date=April 21, 2016}}</ref>
Studies have found mixed results when it comes to the effects of incarceration on pregnancy outcomes. Some studies have found that incarceration correlates to lower [[birth weight]], and an increased chance of [[Complications of pregnancy|complications in the pregnancy]]; others have found the opposite: that incarceration is associated with higher birth weight and a decreased likelihood of [[Preterm birth|premature delivery]]. However, the latter finding may simply speak to the low level of medical care available to women in poverty in the free world.<ref name=":1" />
A 1996 study conducted by the [[National Council on Crime and Delinquency]] (NCCD) on women in California, Connecticut, and Florida state prisons found a lack of adequate prenatal and postnatal medical care, [[prenatal nutrition]], level of [[methadone maintenance]] for opiate-dependent pregnant inmates, education regarding childbirth and parenting, and preparation for the mother's separation from her child.<ref name=":2" /> Often, inmates report receiving no regular pelvic exams or sonograms, and little to no information about proper prenatal care and nutrition.<ref name=":1" /> Prison diets often lack proper nutrition, particularly for the changing and special dietary needs of pregnant women, and many women prisoners report not being allowed to alter their diets during their pregnancy.<ref name=":1" />
Despite the lack or low quality of prenatal care in most institutions, many correctional facilities have made strides to provide adequate care. For example, Washington State has a program called the Birth Attendants Prison Doula project, which provides support to incarcerated pregnant and [[Postpartum period|postpartum]] women.<ref name=":1" /> When asked about her prison's response to pregnancy, Boo, an inmate in an Arizona correctional facility, said:
{{quote|text=They're real good people to me... I get taken care of in here very well. They give us three pregnancy bags a day which contain two cartons of milk, two orange juices, and two fruits, and you get three pills three times a day during breakfast, lunch, and dinner.<ref name=":1" />}}
In general, pregnant inmates are transported to outside medical facilities to give birth, because most correctional facilities are not medically equipped to provide such services. These transports often result in complications due to the risk of injury to both the mother and the child, and due to the additional stress.<ref name=":0" />
The practice of [[shackling]] inmates, both in transit to the hospital and during [[Childbirth|labor]], is also common at many facilities. Forty-one states permit the use of restraints during transport to the hospital, and twenty-three states and the federal government permit the use of restraints during labor. These restraints may include [[Belly chain (restraint)|belly chains]], shackles, handcuffs, or nylon "soft restraints." The use of restraints on women so far into their pregnancy and during labor poses many health risks. Restraints inhibit the movement of a woman, something that aids the progression of the labor and alleviates some of her discomfort. They may also hinder the ability of health care professionals to respond quickly to emergencies during the labor. Organizations such as [[Amnesty International]] have pressured correctional facilities to stop the use of shackles on pregnant women, pointing out the fact that most pregnant women are incarcerated for nonviolent offenses and pose no risk (especially during childbirth), so the restraints are unnecessary.<ref name=":1" /> Maria Jones, a pregnant inmate, described her experience being shackled during labor:
{{quote|text=Because I was shackled to the bed, they couldn't remove the lower part of the bed for the delivery, and they couldn't put my feet in the stirrups. My feet were still shackled together, and I couldn't get my legs apart. The doctor called for the [[Prison officer|officer]], but the officer had gone down the hall. No one else could unlock the shackles, and my baby was coming but I couldn't open my legs.<ref name=":1" />}}
=== HIV/AIDS === Incarcerated women are 15 times more likely to be infected with [[HIV]] than are women who are free,<ref name=":1" /> and are also more than twice as likely than incarcerated men to be infected with HIV.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Weatherhead|first=Kendra|date=2003|title=Cruel but not Unusual Punishment: The Failure to Provide Adequate Medical Treatment to Female Prisoners in the United States|url=http://uu5bm5kq6z.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info:sid/summon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Cruel+but+not+Unusual+Punishment%3A+The+Failure+to+Provide+Adequate+Medical+Treatment+to+Female+Prisoners+in+the+United+States&rft.jtitle=Health+Matrix%3A+Journal+of+Law-Medicine&rft.au=Kendra+Weatherhead&rft.date=2003-07-01&rft.pub=Case+Western+Reserve+University+Health+Matrix%3A+Journal+of+Law-Medicine&rft.volume=13&rft.spage=429&rft.epage=429&rft.externalDocID=13_Health_Matrix_429_srctype_smi_srcid_3B15_key_8f97eab4a9b73e1350b316e5e67dcf23|journal=Health Matrix: Journal of Law-Medicine|doi=|pmid=|access-date=May 28, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Chandler|first=Cynthia|date=2003|title=Death and Dying in America: The Prison Industrial Complex's Impact on Women's Health|url=http://uu5bm5kq6z.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info:sid/summon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Death+and+Dying+in+America%3A+The+Prison+Industrial+Complex%27s+Impact+on+Women%27s+Health&rft.jtitle=Berkeley+Women%27s+Law+Journal&rft.au=Cynthia+Chandler&rft.date=2003-01-01&rft.pub=The+Regents+of+the+University+of+California+on+behalf+of&rft.volume=18&rft.spage=40&rft.epage=304&rft.externalDocID=18_Berkeley_Women_s_L_J_40_srctype_smi_srcid_3B15_key_8549afa72665cf5fdaf04f403446adfb&paramdict=en-US|journal=Berkeley Women's Law Journal|doi=|pmid=|access-date=May 31, 2016}}</ref> For example, in New York, a state which does [[blind testing]], 14.6% of incarcerated women and 7.3% of incarcerated men tested positive for HIV.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title=Public Health Behind Bars: From Prisons to Communities|last=Balis|first=Andrea F.|publisher=Springer New York|year=2007|isbn=|editor-last=Greifinger|editor-first=Robert B.|location=New York, N.Y.|pages=320–332|chapter=Female Prisoners and the Case for Gender-Specific Reentry Programs}}</ref> The 1996 NCCD study found that female African American and Hispanic/Latina inmates were significantly more likely than their White counterparts to report testing positive for HIV.<ref name=":2" /> Many of the same social factors that increase the likelihood of incarceration for women, such as poverty, race, gender, and a history of victimization, are also correlated to HIV infection.<ref name=":1" />
A 2000 study by the [[American Correctional Association]] found that mandatory HIV testing is conducted upon intake in 23 states, and that a few also provide 6-month follow-up testing.<ref name=":0" /> Most prisons test inmates who either ask to be tested, or display symptoms of HIV (this is the policy in 44 out of 51 jurisdictions), and fifteen states also specifically test inmates that are in high-risk groups.<ref name=":5" /> Three states, the District of Columbia, and the [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]] test inmates upon release.<ref name=":5" /> The same American Correctional Association study also found that most prisons provide HIV-positive individuals with medications while they are in the prison, may provide them with a small supply after they are released, and may also direct them towards community resources where they can receive more medication.<ref name=":0" /> Treatment of inmates who have tested positive for HIV varies greatly from state to state. For example, in New Jersey, female HIV positive prisoners were shackled to their beds for up to six months after being diagnosed.<ref name=":7" /> However, Ohio and New York, among other states, have infirmaries specifically adapted to attend to the needs of inmates with HIV/AIDS, and allow some inmates to reside in a hospital for treatment.<ref name=":7" /> In addition to this, New York State's Division of Health Services department does regular evaluations of the state prisons' services for AIDS patients, and also provides space for support groups to meet, and patients to be counseled on their illness.<ref name=":7" />
Women's symptoms and treatment needs for HIV infection are quite different from those of men, but the treatment resources for incarcerated women are often limited.<ref name=":2" /> The treatment of HIV requires a specialist, and generally, prison doctors don't have adequate training to treat women effectively.<ref name=":5" /> Or, prisons often do not have adequate facilities, staff, or a follow-up treatment system.<ref name=":5" /> For example, the 1996 NCCD study also found that within the entire California women's prison system, one of the largest in the nation, there was only one full-time specialist able to provide "gender-specific treatment" to women with HIV.<ref name=":2" /> Male prisoners, however, did have access to gender-specific HIV treatment.<ref name=":2" />
=== Abortion === Federal courts have established, according to constitutional law, that prisoners retain the right to have an abortion once they are incarcerated.<ref name=":4" /> However, state standards regarding abortion for incarcerated women are unclear - actions are often left up to the discretion of prison officials on a case-by-case basis.<ref name=":4" />
Most state abortion policies are written and approved without going through the administrative process which other policies are generally subject to; thus, they are frequently incomplete. In fact, fourteen state [[Department of Corrections|DOCs]] have no official written abortion policies, and others simply will not release or publish their policies. Alaska has a provision which bans abortion funding in its policy on general medical services, but no specific policy guidelines on abortion. Other states may not define the exact type of abortions they pay for.<ref name=":4" /> Most states require that women pay for all of the costs of an abortion procedure, including transportation to the clinic (which is often far due to prisons' rural locations, and the urban locations of most abortion clinics), security, and the actual surgery. Minnesota and Wisconsin are the only two states which explicitly mention in their policies that they pay for abortions if a woman has been raped. The policy of the Federal Bureau of Prisons since 1987 has been to pay for abortion only in the cases of rape or life endangerment (although they do pay for transportation to the clinic).<ref name=":4" /> Women's experiences and perceptions of their own access to abortion reflect these policies. In a nationwide survey of correctional health care and inmates' access to abortion, 68% of respondents said that women within their prison were allowed to have an abortion if they requested one.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Sufrin|first=Carolyn B.|date=2009|title=Incarcerated Women and Abortion Provision: A Survey of Correctional Health Providers|jstor=20462705|journal=Perspectives on Sexual and Reproductive Health|doi=10.1363/4100609|pmid=|volume=41|pages=6–11}}</ref> However, many respondents also stated that although their prison did allow access to abortion, women receive little to no help with arranging an appointment, paying for the procedure, and getting themselves to the clinic.<ref name=":10" />
=== Other reproductive health care ===
==== Cancer and general gynecological care ==== According to the U.S. Department of Justice [[Bureau of Justice Statistics]], [[cancer]] is one of the leading causes of death for women (both inside and outside prison), and one-quarter of deaths of incarcerated women due to cancer are from [[Breast cancer|breast]], [[Cervical cancer|cervical]], [[Ovarian cancer|ovarian]], and [[uterine cancer]].<ref name=":1" /> In particular, women in prison are at a high risk for contracting cervical cancer due to their high rates of substance abuse and diseases such as [[hepatitis C]], HIV, and other STIs.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Magee|first=Catherine G.|last2=Hult|first2=Jen R.|last3=Turalba|first3=Ruby|last4=McMillan|first4=Shelby|date=2005|title=Preventive Care for Women in Prison: A Qualitative Community Health Assessment of the Papanicolaou Test and Follow-Up Treatment at a California State Women's Prison|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/215091831?pq-origsite=summon|journal=American Journal of Public Health|doi=10.2105/ajph.2005.063677|pmid=|access-date=May 31, 2016|pmc=1449425}}</ref><ref name=":9" /> However, reproductive health care reform in prisons generally focuses on pregnancy or HIV.<ref name=":1" />
Incarcerated women have higher rates of STIs and gynecologic infections than non-incarcerated women.<ref name=":1" /> In fact, one study estimated that about 9% of incarcerated women tested positive for [[gonococcus]] infection, and between 11 and 17% of incarcerated women are infected with [[chlamydia infection|chlamydia]].<ref name=":5" /> However, not every infected woman will be diagnosed and given treatment, because many prisons only test women who request to be tested, or show symptoms.<ref name=":5" />
States often have their own legislation regarding correctional health care, but it doesn't always completely take into consideration the complexities of women's reproductive health. For example, the [[New York State Department of Corrections and Community Supervision]] (DOCCS) has issued two main documents which outline their institutional health care policies: the Health Services Policy Manual, and the Women's Health Primary Care Practice Guideline (first published in 2000, and updated in 2008 and 2011). Within these documents, the Patient Bill of Rights includes the right of a patient to respectful care, the right to refuse treatment, and the right to complete information regarding a diagnosis; the Professional Code of Ethics outlines the standards that staff must follow, including having a respect for [[human dignity]], and a [[Doctor–patient relationship|professional relationship with the patient]]. The DOCCS does not monitor how well facilities actually adhere to these standards, and there are no consequences for those who do not. Also, many women are not informed of their patient's rights, so are unaware when standards have been breached.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Kraft-Stolar|first=Tamar|date=2015|title=Reproductive Injustice: The State of Reproductive Health Care for Women in New York State Prisons|url=http://www.correctionalassociation.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Reproductive-Injustice-FULL-REPORT-FINAL-2-11-15.pdf|journal=Women in Prison Project of the Correctional Association of New York|doi=|pmid=|access-date=April 25, 2016}}</ref>
The DOCCS has no written policies on [[pregnancy test]]s, [[pregnancy options counseling]], [[abortion]], [[ectopic pregnancy]], [[miscarriage]], [[stillbirth]], nutrition for pregnant and nursing women, or [[Hysterectomy|hysterectomies]], and has incomplete policies regarding [[menopause]], vitamins, health care for pregnant women, women in labor, or women who have recently given birth. The DOCCS policies stray from community standards in the areas of the starting age for yearly GYN check-ups, the frequency of breast exams and [[Pap smear]]s, follow-up for abnormal Pap smears, frequency of prenatal visits and [[Obstetric ultrasonography|ultrasounds]], and the time frame for postpartum check-ups for women who have a [[Caesarean section]].<ref name=":6" />
The Federal Bureau of Prisons' policy is to provide each inmate with a complete [[medical exam]] (which includes [[gynecological]] and [[obstetrical]] history) within 30 days of admission.<ref name=":0" /> The BOP currently{{specify|date=June 2016}} adheres to the standards for yearly exams put forth by the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology.<ref name=":0" /> According to a 1997 survey, approximately 90 percent of the inmates in women's state prisons reported having received a gynecologic exam from their institution upon intake.<ref name=":1" /> Additionally, an American Correctional Association study found that most women's correctional institutions provided [[Obstetrics and gynaecology|OB/GYN]] services, [[Prenatal care|prenatal]] and postpartum care, [[mammography]], and Pap smears upon request.<ref name=":0" /> Fewer provided counseling for inmates regarding their reproductive health,<ref name=":0" /> many correctional facilities do not provide follow-up exams, and screenings often do not continue on the recommended schedule.<ref name=":1" /> In a New York city juvenile detention facility, the 5,000 youth who went through the system annually were all served by a single physician. Less than one-third of the inmates received a Pap smear test, and one in five were tested for [[gonorrhea]], chlamydia, and [[syphilis]].<ref name=":1" />
Women often report long delays and wait times in signing up for appointments with a GYN doctor, and in getting treated. For example, more than half of respondents in a survey of incarcerated women in New York state prisons said that they were not able to see the GYN when necessary, and 47% of respondents stated that their problems became worse in the time that they had to wait. In one extreme case, Sara, a woman incarcerated in New York, had to wait seven months before she was finally diagnosed with an aggressive cancer. Another woman had to wait four months to receive a colposcopy, a follow-up to her Pap test.<ref name=":6" /> Another woman at the same prison wrote:
{{quote|I’ve never seen the GYN. I dropped a tab [note to the doctor] explaining to them about being diagnosed with abnormal cells. . . and how I’d like to get a check-up, but no one answered. This was six months ago.<ref name=":6" />}}
In a [[qualitative study]] on the experiences of incarcerated women with the [[Pap test|Papanicolaou test]] (a test which screens for cervical cancer) in California state prisons, researchers found a lack of communication between medical providers within the prison, which tended to result in long delays or cancellations of treatment, no standardized process for scheduling a Pap test, and a lack of education and explanation regarding both the test itself, and how to fill out the medical forms associated with it.<ref name=":8" />
In addition to this, women who aren't called in for a Pap test are sometimes required to pay a $5 fee if they request one. This can be a significant barrier to requesting a test, considering an average prisoner's wage is around 7 to 13 cents per hour.<ref name=":8" />
In the same study, women brought attention to the discomfort suffered by inmates with personal histories of sexual abuse and victimization when they were forced to be examined by a male physician.<ref name=":8" /> Women interviewed in New York State prisons had similar complaints about their physicians' seeming lack of awareness of female prisoners' past traumas, and the lack of explanation of the procedures.<ref name=":6" /> One woman stated:
{{quote|text=Ninety-nine percent of the women have been abused or raped. To have a man take us into an office the size of a closet... stripped down... [it's] rough and hurts us... it takes us right back to the beginning."<ref name=":8" />}}
==== Perceptions of Medical Care ==== Another consideration in correctional reproductive health care is the relationship between the prisoner-patients and the physicians. Studies have shown that female inmates often report distrust of physicians and disappointment with their interactions with providers.<ref name=":8" />
Researchers have found that most of the women interviewed in the 2005 California state prison study had negative perceptions of their gynecologic tests and treatment.<ref name=":8" /> According to the women interviewed, the prison doctors who performed their tests were often unprofessional and disrespectful.<ref name=":8" /> One woman described her experience, saying: "They expect us to give them respect, but they don't respect us. They treat us like we are animals just because we are incarcerated."<ref name=":8" /> The [[Prisons in California|California prison system]] employs [[corrections officer]]s who are also trained to be licensed nurses (called medical technical assistants). Similarly, in Chicago, the county jails train corrections officers as [[doula]]s and [[birth attendant]]s.<ref name=":4" /> Inmates generally must request medical treatment through either these officers, or through other, non-medically trained correctional staff, and studies have shown that female patients' complaints and requests for medical assistance are often not taken as seriously as those of male patients.<ref name=":2" /> The simultaneous positions that these officers hold as both security personnel and medical caretakers or advocates may contribute to female inmates' distrust of them.<ref name=":4" />
A 1999 study found that female inmates were more likely than their male counterparts to think that their access to health care was inadequate and that their quality of care was low compared to the care male prisoners were given. Women in this study also visited the health care facility more often than their male counterparts and reported being healthy less often than men did.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lindquist|first=Christine H|last2=Lindquist|first2=Charles A|date=2009|title=Health Behind Bars: Utilization and Evaluation of Medical Care Among Jail Inmates|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023%2FA%3A1018794305843|journal=Journal of Community Health|volume=24|issue=4|pages=285|doi=10.1023/A:1018794305843|pmid=10463472|access-date=April 20, 2016}}</ref>
== Issues in correctional reproductive health care ==
=== Lack of resources === A lack of resources, specifically of adequate staff, within facilities is largely what contributes to the substandard care of inmates.<ref name=":1" /> For example, although California's prison system is the largest in the country, an obstetrician/gynecologist was not hired at the [[California Institution for Women]] (CIW) until pregnant prisoners in California filed a class action lawsuit (Harris v. McCarthy) against CIW. The [[Valley State Prison|Valley State Prison for Women]] (VSPW), another prison in California, had just two OB/GYN doctors on staff in 2000 (one of whom was indicted on four counts of sexual misconduct and eventually fired). Albion, a women's prison in New York State, has 1,000 prisoners, but only one GYN doctor, who works only 16 hours per week.<ref name=":6" /> Taconic, another facility in New York, which holds about 370 women, has no GYN doctor on site.<ref name=":6" /> In these cases, routine GYN care falls to the general nurse practitioner or Medical Director.<ref name=":6" /> In addition to the lack of staff, medical doctors are often not on duty on the weekends and during evening hours.<ref name=":3" /> This can be dangerous if medical emergencies arise during non-business hours. For example, a prisoner in CIW in 1997 went into labor over the weekend, when there was only one nurse on duty. The nurse strapped the woman into a gurney, but refused to help with her labor. When the baby was born not breathing, the nurse had to call paramedics, because she was unable to activate the breathing apparatus. By the time the newborn was transported to the hospital, he was declared brain dead.<ref name=":3" />
The difficulty with recruiting qualified staff can be attributed to both the physical isolation of women's prisons (often placed in areas that are considered undesirable to live in, where there are few available medical professionals), and to the relative lack of medical resources and low salaries that prisons offer to medical staff.<ref name=":2" /> Dr. Valda Chijide, a former HIV doctor in an Alabama prison, for instance, resigned from her position due to inadequate support. In this case, the HIV unit was rat-infested, with broken windows covered in plastic.<ref name=":1" />
=== Privatization of prison health care === There is also a trend towards privatizing health care by hiring outside, for-profit health care companies to provide medical care to inmates.<ref name=":1" /> According to a 1996 survey by the [[National Institute of Corrections]] (NIC), forty-four state Departments of Corrections contract out at least some of their medical care to private vendors - in 1996 this amounted to $706 million.<ref name=":4" />
This can result in a lack of accountability, as proper monitoring makes a contract more expensive.<ref name=":4" /> Oversight is often lacking. In Alabama, the same official who previously held a high level position at Prison Health Services, one of the nation's largest private vendors, now works in a position within the Alabama Department of Corrections which requires her to oversee Prison Health's compliance to the contract.<ref name=":1" /> Prison Health Services, which has cared for 237,000 inmates, has had to pay millions of dollars in fines and settlements due to inadequate care.<ref name=":1" /> In another example, according to a former supervisory nurse of a jail operated by [[Corizon|Correctional Medical Services]] (CMS), a large private contractor, the jail would often release pregnant women when they went into labor, and then arrest them again after they gave birth, in order to avoid having to pay for the inmates' medical expenses.<ref name=":4" />
Lack of accountability also results due to varying state and federal laws on private contractors' liability for medical abuse and neglect.<ref name=":4" /> Private contractors can be challenged under the same federal civil rights law that applies to state and local governments, but these corporations cannot be sued for unconstitutional medical practices.<ref name=":4" />
==See also== * [[Incarceration in the United States]] * [[Incarceration of women in the United States]] * [[Reproductive health]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Imprisonment and detention of women in the United States]] [[Category:Healthcare in the United States]] [[Category:Sexual health]]

Pared-back interiors have become a key trend in dining Awards|url=http://www.australiandesignreview.com/news/34305-restaurant-and-bar-design-awards|website=Australian Design Review|publisher=Australian Design Review|accessdate=20 September 2013|ref=Australian Design Review}}</ref><ref name="RESTAURANT & BAR DESIGN AWARDS 2013">{{cite web|last1=Restaurant & Bar Design Awards 2013|first1=Restaurant & Bar Design Awards 2013|title=The 2013 winners were announced overnight...|url=http://www.indesignlive.hk/articles/in-review/restaurant-bar-design-awards-2013|website=In Design Live Hong Kong|publisher=Ola Bednarczuk|accessdate=16 September 2013|ref=RESTAURANT & BAR DESIGN AWARDS 2013}}</ref><ref name="Mondo Arc">{{cite web|last1=Mondo Arc|first1=Mondo Arc|title=Chan shines at Restaurant & Bar Design Awards|url=http://www.mondoarc.com/news/979253/chan_shines_at_restaurant_bar_design_awards.html|website=Mondo Arc|publisher=Mondo Arc|accessdate=14 July 2011|ref=Mondo Arc|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120214175936/http://www.mondoarc.com/news/979253/chan_shines_at_restaurant_bar_design_awards.html|archivedate=14 February 2012|df=}}</ref><ref name="Dexinger 2013 Restaurant & Bar Design Awards">{{cite web|last1=Dexinger|first1=Dexinger|title=Winners of the 2013 Restaurant & Bar Design Awards|url=http://www.dexigner.com/news/26956|website=Dexinger|publisher=Levent Ozler|accessdate=13 September 2013|ref=Dexinger}}</ref><ref name="Hospitality Interiors - Restaurant & Bar Design Awards shortlist announced">{{cite web|last1=Hospitality Interiors|first1=Hospitality Interiors|title=Restaurant & Bar Design Awards shortlist announced|url=http://www.hospitality-interiors.net/news/articles/2013/06/486359708-restaurant-bar-design-awards-shortlist-announced|website=Hospitality Interiors|publisher=Katie Sherry|accessdate=24 June 2014|ref=Hospitality Interiors}}</ref><ref name="British Hospitality Association - BHA members winning Restaurant & Bar Design Awards">{{cite web|last1=British Hospitality Association|first1=British Hospitality Association|title=BHA members winning Restaurant & Bar Design Awards|url=http://www.bha.org.uk/bha_members_news/bha-members-winning-restaurant-bar-design-awards/|website=British Hospitality Association|publisher=British Hospitality Association|accessdate=26 September 2014|ref=British Hospitality Association}}</ref><ref name="Architecture AU - Australians scoop international awards for restaurant and bar design">{{cite web|last1=Architecture|first1=AU|title=Australians scoop international awards for restaurant and bar design|url=http://architectureau.com/articles/australians-scoop-international-awards-for-restaurant-and-bar-design/|website=Architecture AU|publisher=Architecture AU|accessdate=26 September 2014|ref=Architecture AU}}</ref> is an annual award dedicated to recognising the [[design]] and [[architecture]] of food and beverage spaces internationally. The Restaurant & Bar Design Awards is an independent award system, set up by Marco Rebora <ref name="Marco Rebora">{{cite book|last1=Rebora|first1=Marco|title=Marco Rebora|publisher=Taschen|isbn=978-3836546683|url=http://www.taschen.com/pages/en/catalogue/design/all/02882/facts.restaurant_bar_design.htm}}</ref> in 2008 in the [[United Kingdom]] with the encouragement of a panel of judges, including the editor-in-chief of [[Wallpaper (magazine)|Wallpaper*]], Tony Chambers.
Since the first awards in 2009 there have been over 5,000 entries from [[design]] and [[architectural]] industries and [[hospitality]] organisations around the world.
Each year the awards are judged by a new panel of representatives from the fields of [[art]], [[architecture]], [[design]] and [[gastronomy]]. Notable judges have included [[Ian Callum]], [[Mark Hix]],<ref name="Mark Hix">{{cite web|last1=Hix|first1=Mark|title=Chicken and Steak|url=http://www.cntraveller.com/recommended/food/restaurant-and-bar-style-awards|website=Condé Nast Traveller|publisher=Condé Nast Traveller|accessdate=1 Nov 2013}}</ref> [[Gerry Judah]], [[Yotam Ottolenghi]], [[Thomas Heatherwick]], [[Julia Peyton-Jones]] and [[Karim Rashid]]. The winners are awarded at annual ceremonies at a chosen host venue affiliated with the award. In 2012 the ceremony was held at The [[Royal Institute of British Architects]] (RIBA).
Restaurant & Bar Design Awards organises a year-round programme of events based in the UK and most recently Internationally with an aim to build a network between entrants, judges, partners and sponsors.
In 2014 [[Taschen]] <ref>{{cite book|last1=Wiedemann|first1=Julius|title=Restaurant & bar design|date=2014|publisher=TASCHEN|location=Köln|isbn=978-3836546683|url=http://www.taschen.com/pages/en/catalogue/design/all/02882/facts.restaurant_bar_design.htm}}</ref> publications published a book, ''Restaurant & Bar Design'' dedicated to the ongoing work of the Awards.
== Categories== Each year the Restaurant & Bar Design Awards acknowledges two overall winners under the categories of Best [[Bar (establishment)|Bar]] and Best [[Restaurant]].
The number of additional category winners varies each year. The inaugural award in 2008/2009 was open to entrants from UK and identified nine category winners. In 2009/10 the awards became International and introduced two more category winners under the titles International [[Restaurant]] and International [[Bar (establishment)|Bar]]. The awards also have a number of sub-categories.
== Overall Winners == *2009 ** The Olde Bell Inn (Hurley, UK) <ref name="The Olde Bell, Hurley">{{cite web|last1=The Olde Bell, Hurley|first1=The Olde Bell, Hurley|title=The Olde Bell, Hurley|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/restaurants/10238614/The-Olde-Bell-Hurley-restaurant-review.html|website=Telegraph|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref> / Studioilse ** Carbon (London, UK) / B3 Designers *2010 ** Galvin La Chapelle (London, UK) <ref name="The Telegraph - London restaurant guide: Galvin La Chapelle">{{cite web|last1=The|first1=Telegraph|title=With the opening of their third London restaurant, Chris and Jeff Galvin have struck gold once again....|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/restaurants/6718070/London-restaurant-guide-Galvin-La-Chapelle-London-E1.html|website=The Telegraph|publisher=Jasper Gerard|accessdate=4 December 2009|ref=Galvin La Chapelle}}</ref> / DesignLSM ** The Tote (India) <ref name="de zeen magazine - The Tote by Serie Architects">{{cite web|last1=de zeen|first1=magazine|title=The Tote by Serie Architects|url=http://www.dezeen.com/2009/12/07/the-tote-by-serie-architects/|website=de zeen magazine|publisher=de zeen magazine|accessdate=7 December 2009|ref=Rose Etherington}}</ref><ref name="Arch Daily - The Tote / Serie Architects">{{cite web|last1=Arch|first1=Daily|title=The Tote / Serie Architects|url=http://www.archdaily.com/43090/the-tote-serie-architects|website=Arch Daily|publisher=Karen Cilento|accessdate=8 December 2009|ref=Arch Daily}}</ref> / Serie Architects *2011 ** Busaba Eathai (Bicester, UK) <ref name="The Telegraph - Busaba Eathai, Bicester Village, restaurant review">{{cite web|last1=The|first1=Telegraph|title=The interior of Busaba Eathai, a Thai restaurant in Bicester Village, is dazzling...|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/restaurants/8850426/Busaba-Eathai-Bicester-Village-restaurant-review.html|website=The Telegraph|publisher=Zoe Williams|accessdate=30 October 2011|ref=The Telegraph}}</ref> / David Archer Architects ** Smack (Leamington Spa, UK) / Steve Smith & Adrian Baynes *2012 ** A Cantina (Spain) <ref name="Arch Daily - A Cantina">{{cite web|last1=A Cantina|first1=A Cantina|title=A Cantina / Estudio Nomada|url=http://www.archdaily.com/290522/a-cantina-estudio-nomada|website=Arch Daily|publisher=Arch Daily|accessdate=7 November 2012|ref=Arch Daily - A Cantina}}</ref> / Estudio Nomada ** Graffiti (Bulgaria) / Studio Mode *2013 ** Höst <ref name="Höst">{{cite web|last1=(Denmark)|first1=Höst|title=In good taste|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/809c0ce2-d878-11e2-b4a4-00144feab7de.html|website=Financial Times|publisher=Financial Times|accessdate=21 June 2013}}</ref> (Denmark) / NORM Architects ** Atrium Champagne Bar <ref name="Atrium Champagne Bar">{{cite web|last1=(London)|first1=Atrium Champagne Bar|title=Atrium Champagne Bar|url=http://www.domusweb.it/en/news/2013/12/23/atrium_champagne_bar.html|website=DOMUS|publisher=DOMUS|accessdate=2 January 2014}}</ref> (London, UK) / [[Foster and Partners]] *2014 ** FEI (China) / A.N.D. ** Les Haras (France) <ref name="Interior Design - Les Haras">{{cite web|last1=Interior|first1=Design|title=Royal Studs: Jouin Manku Renovates Former Louis Xv Farm|url=http://www.interiordesign.net/projects/detail/2281-royal-studs-jouin-manku-renovates-former-louis-xv-farm/|website=Interior Design|publisher=Judy Fayard|accessdate=23 January 2014|ref=Interior Design - Les Haras}}</ref> / Jouin Manku *2015 ** Dandelyan (London, UK) / Design Research Studio ** The Jane (Belgium) / Studio Piet Boon *2016 ** Blue Wave (Barcelona, Spain) / El Equipo Creativo ** German Gymnasium (London, UK) <ref name="Arch Daily - {{refimprove|date=October 2017}}
The '''Shelford Group''' represents ten of the leading NHS multi-specialty academic healthcare centres in England. Founded in 2011, the Group seeks to share best practice and constructively engage with government, Parliament and industry.
The current Chair is Nick Moberly, Chief Executive of King's College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust.
==Membership== The member organisations are: * [[University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust]] * [[University College London Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]] * [[Sheffield Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]] * [[Oxford University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]] * [[Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]] * [[King's College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust]] * [[Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust]] * [[Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust]] * [[Central Manchester University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]] * [[Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]]
==Key facts== * The Shelford Group provide high quality health services worth nearly £10bn p.a., which is equivalent to 10% of the whole NHS England budget and over 13% of NHS providers. * About one third of the Group's aggregate income is for specialised services and the Group provide nearly one quarter of all specialised services commissioned by NHS England. * They employ over 100,000 NHS staff, including 15,000 doctors and dentists, and 40,000 nurses, midwives and health visitors. * The Group treats millions of patients each year, with the member trusts seeing over 1.6 million A&E attendances in 2015. * The Group have over 190,000 Foundation Trust members. * Between them, the Group's ten Chief Executives have over 150 years of CEO experience. * The Group are national and international hubs of research, education and innovation, providing some of the most complex and specialised healthcare in the world. * In aggregate, they have earned £555m of research funding for five years from 2017 from the National Institute of Health Research, which is over two thirds of the total funding nationally. * The Shelford trusts are all Biomedical Research Centres, in partnership with their universities, and include the top four BRCs in the country. * Shelford trusts are 8 of the 13 NHS Genomic Medicine Centres in England, leading the way to deliver the 100,000 Genome Project.
==External links== *[http://shelfordgroup.org Official website]
[[Category:National Health Service (England)]] [[Category:2011 establishments in England]]
{{NHS-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Sleep onset''' is the transition from wakefulness into sleep. Sleep onset usually transmits into [[non-rapid eye movement sleep]] (NREM sleep) but under certain circumstances (e.g. [[narcolepsy]]) it is possible to transit from wakefulness directly into [[rapid eye movement sleep]] (REM sleep).
==History== During the 1920s an obscure disorder that caused [[encephalitis]] and attacked the part of the brain that regulates sleep influenced Europe and North America. Although the virus that caused this disorder was never identified, the psychiatrist and neurologist [[Constantin von Economo]] decided to study this disease and identified a key component in the sleep-wake regulation. He identified the pathways that regulated wakefulness and sleep onset by studying the parts of the brain that were affected by the disease and the consequences it had on the [[circadian rhythm]]. He stated that the pathways that regulated sleep onset are located between the brain stem and the [[basal forebrain]]. His discoveries were not appreciated until the last two decades of the 20th century when the pathways of sleep onset were found to reside in the exact place that Constantin von Economo stated.<ref name="Saper, Scammell, Lu 05">{{cite journal |author1=Saper, C.B. |author2=Scammell, T.E. |author3=Lu, J. |title=Hypothalamic regulation of sleep and circadian rhythms |journal=Nature |volume=437 |pages=1257–1264 |year=2005 |doi=10.1038/nature04284 |pmid=16251950 |issue=7063}}</ref>
==Physiological overview{{anchor|Physiological Overview}}== Sleep electrophysiological measurements can be made by attaching electrodes to the scalp to measure the electroencephalogram (EEG) and to the chin to monitor muscle activity, recorded as the electromyogram (EMG). Electrodes attached around the eyes monitor eye movements, recorded as the electro-oculogram (EOG).<ref name="Carlson 2013 744">{{cite book|last=Carlson|first=Neil|title=Physiology of Behavior|year=2013|publisher=Pearson|location=University of Massachusetts, Amherst|isbn=978-0-205-23939-9|pages=744}}</ref>
Von Economo, in his studies, noticed that lesions in the connection between the midbrain and the diencephalon caused prolonged sleepiness and therefore proposed the idea of an ascending arousal system. During the past few decades major ascending pathways have been discovered with located neurons and respective [[neurotransmitters]]. This pathway divides into two branches: one that ascends to the thalamus and activates the thalamus relay neurons, and another one that activates neurons in the lateral part of the [[hypothalamus]] and the [[basal forebrain]], and throughout the [[cerebral cortex]]. The cell group involved in the first pathway is an [[acetylcholine]]-producing cell group called [[pedunculopontine]] and [[laterodorsal tegmental nucleus]](PPT/LDT). These neurons play a crucial role in bridging information in between the thalamus and the cerebral cortex. These neurons have high activation during wakefulness and during [[REM sleep]] and a low activation during [[NREM sleep]]. The second branch originates from monoaminorgenic neurons. These neurons are located in the [[locus coeruleus]], dorsal and median [[raphe nuclei]], ventral periaqueductal grey matter, and [[tuberomammillary nucleus]]. Each group produces a different neurotransmitter. The neurons in the [[locus coeruleus]] produce [[noradrenaline]], as fore the neurons in the dorsal and median [[raphe nuclei]], ventral periaqueductal grey matter, and [[tuberomammillary nucleus]] produce serotonin, dopamine and histamine respectively. They then project onto the hypothalamic peptidergic neurons, which contain melanin-concentrated hormones or [[orexin]], and basal forebrain neurons which contain [[GABA]] and [[acetylcholine]]. These neurons then project onto the [[cerebral cortex]]. It has also been discovered that lesions to this part of the brain cause prolonged sleep or may produce coma.<ref name="Saper, Scammell, Lu 05"/><ref name="Huang, Urade, Hayaishi 09">{{cite journal |author1=Zhi-Li Haung |author2=Yoshihiro Urade |author3=Osamu Hayaishi |title=Prostanglan and adenosine in the regulation of sleep and wakefulness |journal=Journal of Physiology |volume=437 |page=7:33–38 |year=2009}}</ref><ref name="McGinty, Szymusiak 08">{{cite journal |author1=McGinty, D |author2=Szymusiak, R |title= Hypothalamic regulation of sleep and arousal |journal=Frontiers in Bioscience |volume=8 |pages=1257–1264 |year=2008 |doi=10.2741/1159}}</ref><ref name="Gallopin, et al. 05">{{cite journal |author1=Gallopin, T |author2=Luppi, PH |author3=Cauli, B |author4=Urade, Y |author5=Rossier, J |author6=Hayaishi, O |author7=Lambolez, B |author8=Fort, P |title=The endogenous somnogen adenosine excites a subset of sleep-promoting neurons via A2A receptors in the ventrolateral preoptic nucleus |journal=Neuroscience |volume=134 |pages=1377–90 |year=2005 |doi=10.1016/j.neuroscience.2005.05.045 |pmid=16039802 |issue=4}}</ref>
The sleep cycle is normally defined in stages. When an individual first begins to sleep, stage 1 is entered, marked by the presence of some theta activity, which indicates that the firing of neurons in the neocortex is becoming more synchronized, as well as alpha wave activity (smooth electrical activity of 8–12 Hz recorded from the brain, generally associated with a state of relaxation). This stage is a transition between sleep and wakefulness. An individual's eyelids will from time to time slowly open and close and their eyes will roll upward and downward. Before one reaches sound sleep, stage 2 is entered. The EEG during this phase is normally irregular, but contains periods of theta activity, sleep spindles, and K complexes. Sleep spindles are short bursts of waves of 12–14 Hz that occur between two and five times a minute during states 1-4 of sleep. They appear to play a role in memory consolidation, and increased number of sleep spindles are correlated with increased scores on tests of intelligence. K complexes are sudden, sharp waveforms, which, unlike sleep spindles, are usually found only during stage 2 of sleep. They spontaneously occur at the rate of approximately one per minute, but often can be triggered by unexpected noises. It has been found that K complexes consist of isolated periods of inhibition. They appear to be the precursor of delta waves, also known as slow wave sleep, which appear during the deepest levels of sleep. Both these stages are classified as non-REM sleep.<ref name="Carlson 2013 744"/>
==Neural circuit== Sleep onset is finally induced by sleep-promoting neurons, located in the [[ventrolateral preoptic nucleus]] (VLPO). The sleep-promoting neurons are believed to project [[GABA]] type A and [[galanin]], two known inhibitory neurotransmitters, to arousal-promoting neurons, such as histaminergic, serotonergic, orexinergic, noradrenergic, and cholinergic neurons (neurons mentioned above). Levels of acetylcholine, norepinepherine, serotonin, and histamine decrease with the onset of sleep, for they are all wakefulness promoting neurotransmitters.<ref name="Carlson 2013 744"/> Therefore, it is believed that the activation of sleep-promoting neurons causes the inhibition of arousal-promoting neurons, which leads to sleep. Evidence has shown that during the sleep-wake cycle, sleep-promoting neurons and the arousal-promoting neurons have reciprocal discharges, and that during [[NREM sleep]], [[GABA]] receptors increase in the arousal-promoting neurons. This had led some to believe that the increase of [[GABA]] receptors in the arousal-promoting neurons is another pathway of inducing sleep.<ref name="Saper, Scammell, Lu 05"/><ref name="Huang, Urade, Hayaishi 09"/><ref name="McGinty, Szymusiak 08"/><ref name="Gallopin, et al. 05"/>
Specifically, Adenosine is known as the sleep promoting nucleoside neuromodulator. Astrocytes maintain a small stock of nutrients in the form of glycogen. In times of increased brain activity, such as during daytime, this glycogen is converted into fuel for neurons; thus, prolonged wakefulness causes a decrease in the level of glycogen in the brain. A fall in the level of glycogen causes an increase in the level of extracellular adenosine, which has an inhibitory effect in neural activity. This accumulation of adenosine serves as a sleep-promoting substance. Additionally, the production of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine increases in the hippocampus as sleep continues, and also increases in the cortex until REM sleep is reached.<ref name="Carlson 2013 744"/>
The majority of sleep neurons are located in the ventrolateral preoptic area (vlPOA). These sleep neurons are silent until an individual shows a transition from waking to sleep.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Takahashi|first=K|author2=JS Lin |author3=K Sakai |title=Characterization and mapping of sleep-waking specific neurons in the basal forebrain and preoptic hypothalamus in mice|journal=Neuroscience|date=June 16, 2009|volume=161|issue=1|pages=269–292|doi=10.1016/j.neuroscience.2009.02.075|pmid=19285545|url=http://www.hal.inserm.fr/inserm-00383292/document}}</ref> The sleep neurons in the preoptic area receive inhibitory inputs from some of the same regions they inhibit, including the tubermammillary nucleus, raphe nuclei, and locus coeruleus.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chou|first=TC|author2=AA Bjorkum |author3=SE Gaus |author4=J Lu |title=Afferents to the Ventrolateral Preoptic Nucleus|journal=The Journal of Neuroscience|year=2002|volume=22|issue=3|pages=977–990}}</ref> Thus, they are inhibited by histamine, serotonin, and norepinepherine. This mutual inhibition may provide the basis for establishing periods of sleep and waking. A reciprocal inhibition also characterizes an electronic circuit known as the flip-flop. A flip-flop can assume one of two states, usually referred to as on or off. Thus, either the sleep neurons are active and inhibit the wakefulness neurons, or the wakefulness neurons are active and inhibit the sleep neurons, Because these regions are mutually inhibitory, it is impossible for neurons in both sets of regions to be active at the same time. This flip-flop, switching from one state to another quickly, can be unstable.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Saper|first=CB|author2=TC Chou |author3=TE Scammell |title=The sleep twitch: Hypothalamic control of sleep and wakefulness|journal=Trends in Neurosciences|year=2001|volume=24|issue=12|pages=726–731|doi=10.1016/s0166-2236(00)02002-6}}</ref>
==References== <!--See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically--> {{Reflist}}
==See also== * [[Sleep onset latency]] * [[Hypnagogia]]
{{Sleep}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sleep Onset}} [[Category:Sleep|Onset]] [[Category:Unsolved problems in neuroscience]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2018}} {{more footnotes|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox climber | image = | image_size = | name = Susan Erica Fear | nationality = [[Australian]] | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1963|03|18}} | birth_place = [[St Ives, New South Wales]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2006|05|28|1963|03|18}} | death_place = [[Manaslu]] | residence = | height = <!-- {{convert|}} (yyyy) --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|}} (yyyy) --> | typeofclimber = [[Mountaineer]] | highestgrade = | highestredpoint = | highestonsight = | knownfor = | firstascents = | namedroutes = | majorascents = [[Mount Everest]] | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | updated = 17 March 2013 }} '''Susan Erica Fear''' (18 March 1963 – 28 May 2006) was an Australian mountain climber, supporter of the [http://www.hollows.org Fred Hollows Foundation] and a 2005 recipient of the [[Order of Australia]] medal in the Queen's birthday honours. Her life and climbing career is illustrated in her biography ''Fear No Boundary: The Road to Everest and Beyond'', written by fellow climber [[Lincoln Hall (climber)|Lincoln Hall]] and Fear, published in 2005.
== Early life == Fear was born on 18 March 1963 in [[St Ives, New South Wales|St Ives]], [[New South Wales]], Australia, she was the middle child in her family, with two brothers Grahame and John.<ref name=fear.org-bio>{{cite web |title=Biography |url=http://www.suefear.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2&Itemid=2 |publisher=www.suefear.org |accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref> Her parents were Ron and Joan Fear. Her mother Joan died from [[breast cancer]] in May 1988, and her father Ron died unexpectedly of a [[heart attack]] in June 2002.<ref name=book-Fear-no />
Fear attended St Ives North Public School in her primary school years where she was the [[School Captain]], and later attended [[Abbotsleigh]] (7–10) where she was the softball captain, and [[Barker College]] (11–12) in Sydney's north where she was a prefect and the captain of both hockey and cricket. While at school she attained the Duke of Edinburgh's Gold Award.
== Career == After leaving school, Fear took an office job with Wilderness Expeditions, an adventure travel company founded by [[Tim Macartney-Snape]]. That company was later acquired by World Expeditions, and she moved out of the office and into the field. She became an adventure guide and led cross country ski trips in Australia as well as treks in [[Africa]], [[South America]] and [[Asia]]. She was recognized as one of the company's senior guides, leading many physically challenging mountaineering expeditions.
== Climbing career achievements == Between 1997 and 2006 Fear climbed five of the world's fourteen 8,000 metre peaks. Her climbing career took off in 1997 when she led the first successful ascent by an Australian team of [[Makalu|Makalu II]] (7,680 m) in Nepal. She followed this with ascents of [[Cho Oyu]] (8,201 m) in 1998 and [[Shishapangma]] (8,046 m) in 2002. In 2003, Fear climbed [[Mount Everest|Everest]] (8,848 m) from the more difficult Tibetan side on the [[North Col]]. She was the first Australian-born woman and the second Australian woman overall to do so. She then successfully summitted [[Gasherbrum II]] (8,035 m) in Pakistan the following year (2004). Her final climb was to [[Manaslu]] (8,156 m) in 2006, which she successfully summited.
== Recognition == Fear was awarded the [[Order of Australia Medal]] (OAM) in 2005 for her work as Ambassador for [[The Fred Hollows Foundation]] and for services to mountaineering, which will have an eye clinic named after her in [[Dhading Besi]], Nepal. Fear was also named the 2003 Adventurer of the Year by the [[Australian Geographic Society]]. She was an ambassador for the [[Australian Himalayan Foundation]], and also helped raise funds for [[Australian Nepalese Medical Group]].
== Book == Fears' life and climbing career is written about in the biographical book ''Fear No Boundary: The Road to Everest and Beyond'', written by fellow climber Lincoln Hall (with Sue Fear), and first published in Melbourne by Lothian Books in 2005.<ref name=book-Fear-no>{{cite book |last1=Hall|first1=Lincoln with |last2=Fear|first2=Sue |title=Fear No Boundary: The Road to Everest and Beyond |date=2005 |publisher=Lothian |location=South Melbourne |isbn=978-0-7344-0786-3 |url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=i97XAAAACAAJ&dq=Fear+No+Boundary:+The+Road+to+Everest+and+Beyond&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Bvs9VaaXFaPsmAXmiIG4Bg&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA |accessdate=27 April 2015 |via=Google Books}}</ref>
== Final climb == Fear died on Sunday, 28 May 2006,<ref name=fear.org-bio /> when she fell into a crevasse (approx. 7,800 m) while descending from the summit of [[Manaslu]] in Nepal. Manaslu was her fifth climb of a mountain over 8,000 metres. Her body remains on the mountain, honouring an earlier request if she were to die whilst climbing a mountain.<ref name=ABC-diary/> A plaque now lies in memory of her just above the town of [[Bandipur]] on a small hill facing Manaslu.<ref name=ABC-diary>{{cite news |last1=Baillie|first1=Rebecca |title=Sue Fear's video diary from Mount Manaslu |url=http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2008/s2404914.htm |accessdate=27 April 2015 |work=[[The 7.30 Report]]|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=29 October 2008}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/top-climber-in-crevasse-plunge/2006/05/29/1148754915886.html Sydney Morning Herald - Top climber is dead: officials] * [http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2002/08/04/1028157882453.html Sydney Morning Herald - Exploring the not so lonely planet]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox hospital | name = Turning Point Alcohol and Drug Centre | org/group =Eastern Health | logo = | logo_size = | image = | image_size = 225 | alt = | caption = | latitude = | longitude = | coordinates = | location = [[Richmond, Victoria|Richmond]] | region = [[Melbourne]] | state = [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | country = [[Australia]] | healthcare = | funding = | affiliation = | patron = | network = | standards = | emergency = | helipad = | beds = | type = Specialist | speciality = Addiction treatment | founded = 1994 | closed = | demolished = | website = {{URL|https://www.turningpoint.org.au/}} | other_links = | module = }}
'''Turning Point Alcohol and Drug Centre''' is an alcohol and other drugs organisation located in the inner [[Melbourne]][[Australia|(Australia]]) suburb of [[Richmond, Victoria|Richmond]]. Established in 1994 in [[Fitzroy, Victoria|Fitzroy]], the organisation provides [[Medicine|clinical treatment]] and support to those with [[Drug addiction|substance addiction]] issues, as well as conducting [[Clinical trial|clinical]] and [[Epidemiology|epidemiological]] research and development. In addition, the organisation provides education and training to health and welfare professionals.<ref name="turningpoint.org.au">http://www.turningpoint.org.au/about_us.html. Turning Point Alcohol and Drug Centre. Accessed 2007-06-29.</ref>
The organisation's approach to alcohol and other drugs [[Medicine|clinical treatment]] is primarily based upon the [[medical model]] of treatment.<ref name="turningpoint.org.au"/> This includes using an [[Evidence-based medicine|evidence based]] approach to treatment services and implementing [[Harm reduction|harm minimisation]] techniques towards relevant client issues.<ref name="turningpoint.org.au"/>
The organisation amalgamated with public health provider Eastern Health in October 2009, and is formally affiliated with [[Monash University]]. In addition, Turning Point collaborates with international organisations including The [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime|United Nations Office of Drugs and Crime (UNODC)]]; ''International Network of Drug Treatment and Rehabilitation Resource Centres'', [[California State University]]; ''Center for Behavioral Research and Services'', [[Yale University]]; ''Center for Interdisciplinary Research on AIDS'' and The '''International Harm Reduction Association'''.<ref>Turning Point Alcohol and Drug Centre Inc., (2007). ''Turning Point Alcohol & Drug Centre Annual Report 2006''. Fitzroy, Australia. {{ISSN|1443-640X}} (print), {{ISSN|1448-5761}} (online), p. 8.</ref>
[[File:TurningPointHeadOffice2006.JPG|thumb|300px|Turning Point Alcohol and Drug Centre former home on Gertrude St Fitzroy.|right]]
==Services==
===[[Medicine|Clinical]] and [[Forensic science|Forensic]] Treatment and Support===
Turning Point provides [[Counseling|counselling]], [[Case management (mental health)|case management]] and [[primary care]] services from a wide range of [[Health care provider|health professionals]] and practitioners, including; Alcohol and Other Drug Clinicians (more commonly known as ''Case Managers''), Forensic Alcohol and Other Drug Clinicians (''Forensic Case Managers'') [[General practitioner|General Practitioners]], [[Psychiatrist]]s, [[Psychologist]]s (both [[Clinical psychology|''Clinical'']] and ''Counselling''), [[Pharmacist]]s and [[Nurse]]s.<ref name="ReferenceA">http://www.turningpoint.org.au/service_information/si_treatment.html. Turning Point Alcohol and Drug Centre. Accessed 2007-07-01.</ref>
Treatment and support can be provided in the following forms:<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>http://www.turningpoint.org.au/service_information/si_need_help.html. Turning Point Alcohol and Drug Centre. Accessed 2007-07-01.</ref>
* Traditional face to face counselling (see [[Therapeutic relationship|''Therapeutic Relationship'']]). * [[Group therapy]]. * [[Outreach]] response. * Home-based [[Drug withdrawal|withdrawal]]. * [[Telephone counseling|Telephone counselling]]. * [[Online counseling|Online counselling]].
====Specialist [[Pharmacotherapy]] Programs====
Turning Point provides eligible clients access to medically supervised drug substitution [[Pharmacotherapy|pharmacotherapies]] such as [[Methadone]] (see [[Methadone maintenance|Methadone Maintenance]]), [[Buprenorphine|Suboxone]] and [[Buprenorphine|Subutex]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
====Specialist [[Health assessment|Assessment]] and [[Consultant (medicine)|Consultancy]] Services====
Turning Point provides services in the following areas:<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
* [[Health assessment|Alcohol and other drug use assessment]]. * [[Dual diagnosis]] (a combination of a [[mental health]] issue and a [[substance abuse]] issue).<ref>http://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/bhcv2/bhcarticles.nsf/pages/Dual_diagnosis?OpenDocument. Better Health Channel. Accessed 2007-07-01.</ref> * [[Comorbidity]]. * [[Acquired brain injury|Acquired Brain Injury (ABI)]]. * [[Chronic pain]].
====Needle and Syringe Program (NSP)====
Turning Point provides a comprehensive program to the local general public, including the [[Needle-exchange programme|supply and exchange of hypodermic needles]] as well as various other [[Harm reduction|harm minimisation]] provisions.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *Turning Point Alcohol and Drug Centre Inc., (2007). ''Turning Point Alcohol & Drug Centre Annual Report 2006''. Fitzroy, Australia. {{ISSN|1443-640X}} (print), {{ISSN|1448-5761}} (online).
==External links== *[https://www.turningpoint.org.au/ The official website of ''Turning Point Alcohol and Drug Centre''] *[https://www.turningpoint.org.au/about-us ''About Us'' at the official website] *[http://www.directline.org.au/ ''DirectLine'' telephone counselling service website] *[https://www.counsellingonline.org.au/ The official website of ''Counselling Online''] *[http://www.unodc.org/unodc/index.html The official website of The ''United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC)'']

'''Wawrzyniec Jerzy Żuławski''' (14 February 1916 in [[Zakopane]] – 18 August 1957 in the [[Alps]]), also known as ''Wawa'', was a [[Poland|Polish]] [[alpinist]], [[educator]], [[composer]], [[music critic]], and [[musicologist]]. He was a professor of [[Państwowa Wyższa Szkoła Muzyczna in Warsaw]]. Żuławski was an initiator and organiser of Polish alpinism.<ref name="pwn">{{cite encyclopedia|title=Żuławski Wawrzyniec Jerzy|encyclopedia=[[Internetowa encyklopedia PWN]]|url=http://encyklopedia.pwn.pl/haslo.php?id=4003191|accessdate=2007-03-05}}</ref> During [[World War II]] he was a member of [[Armia Krajowa]] and was a soldier during the [[Warsaw Uprising]].
Żuławski published music reviews in ''Ruch Muzyczny'', ''Express Wieczorny'', ''Nowa Kultura''. He also composed orchestral, chamber, piano and vocal pieces.
He was one of the leading Polish alpinists.<ref name="wiem">{{cite encyclopedia|title=Żuławski Wawrzyniec Jerzy|encyclopedia=[[WIEM Encyklopedia]]|url=http://portalwiedzy.onet.pl/11361,,,,zulawski_wawrzyniec_jerzy,haslo.html|accessdate=2007-03-05}}</ref> He died on [[Mont Blanc]] during a rescue action in 1957.
==Notable works==
===Compositions=== * ''Cztery kolędy polskie'', orchestral compositions, 1947 * ''Wierchowe nuty'', vocal compositions for choir and [[violin]] solo, 1955
===Books=== Żuławski was an author of several mountain-related books: * ''Niebieski krzyż'', 1946 * ''Sygnały ze skalnych ścian'', 1954 * ''Tragedie tatrzańskie'', 1956 * ''Skalne lato'', 1957
==Family tree== {{Zulawski family tree}}
==Notes== <references/>

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=July 2010}} {{Infobox person | name = Zheng Ji | image = Zheng Ji.JPG | caption = Zheng Ji in 1935 | birth_date = {{birth date|1900|5|6|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Nanxi District, Yibin|Nanxi]], [[Sichuan]],
[[Qing China]] | death_date = {{death date|2010|7|29|df=y}}
(aged {{age in years and days|1900|5|6|2010|7|29}}) | death_place = [[Nanjing]], [[Jiangsu]],
[[China]] | occupation = [[Nutritionist]] and [[biochemist]] }} '''Zheng Ji''' ({{zh|c=郑集}}) (6 May 1900 – 29 July 2010) was a [[nutritionist]] and a pioneering [[biochemist]] from [[Nanxi District, Yibin|Nanxi]], [[Sichuan]] province, China. He was reputed to be the world's oldest professor and the founder of modern nutrition science in [[China]]. He lived to the [[supercentenarian|age of 110]]. == Career == In 1924 Zheng Ji passed the entrance exam for the Southeast National University (originally known as the Nanjing Advanced Normal School, moving in 1928 to the National Central University, and then to the [[Nanjing University]]) biology department in 1929. In 1930 he went to [[United States|America]] to study, majoring in biochemistry at [[Ohio State University|Ohio State]]. He also attended [[Yale]] and [[Indiana University Bloomington|Indiana University]], and in 1936 he obtained his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]. Upon returning to China he successively served as a research fellow at the Scientific Research Institute of China; as a professor at the Central Medical School; as both a biochemistry professor and department head, simultaneously, at the Eastern China Military Medical School; as a professor at the Number 4 Military Medical College; and as both a biology professor and the head of the biochemistry teaching and research department at the Nanjing Medical School. In 1945, at the Central Medical School, he established a biochemistry research institute to train graduate students. This was the first formal organization in China to teach biochemistry to graduate students, training a large number of students who went on to work in a variety of fields. After turning 70 he began to study the biochemistry of old age, proposing a theory of metabolic imbalance, forming the basis of geriatric biochemistry in China. He participated in the establishment of the Chinese Nutrition Society and, later on, the Biochemistry Society. He was a past chairman of the Central University Professors Association and the first council chair of the Chinese Nutrition Society. Zheng Ji turned 110 in May 2010 and at the time was claimed to be the oldest professor living in the world.{{cite news |title=World's oldest professor turns 109 |url=http://www.cctv.com/program/cultureexpress/20090507/107284.shtml |publisher=[[China Central Television]] |date=7 May 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2010 }} He spent the greater part of his life teaching at the medical school and biology department of Nanjing University. ==Personal life== In recent years prior to his death he sold off family property, such as his family home, using the proceeds to make donations both to the university and to society at large, and to set up both a scholarship for needy students and a scientific endowment.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} Zheng Ji died on 29 July 2010.{{cite news | title = Nanjing: World's oldest professor, who kept working after 100, passes away | date = 2010-07-30 | url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/edu/2010-07/30/c_12389597.htm | work = www.news.cn | accessdate = 2010-08-15 | language = Chinese}} ==See also== *[[List of centenarians (scientists and mathematicians)]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zheng, Ji}} [[Category:Chinese food scientists]] [[Category:Nutritionists]] [[Category:Chinese supercentenarians]] [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:National Central University alumni]] [[Category:Nanjing University alumni]] [[Category:People from Yibin]] [[Category:Writers from Sichuan]] [[Category:Educators from Sichuan]] [[Category:National Central University faculty]] [[Category:Scientists from Sichuan]] [[Category:Chinese biochemists]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:Indiana University alumni]] [[Category:Ohio University alumni]]
